pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, November 8, 2017
shortDescription: Remnant foundThe Washington Times, Houston Chronicle, San Antonio Express-News, Fort Worth Star-Telegram and many other outlets reported on the return
body:
Remnant found

The Washington Times, Houston Chronicle, San Antonio Express-News, Fort Worth Star-Telegram and many other outlets reported on the return of a historic marble stone to the UTA campus. The stone, discovered in a Fort Worth home, is believed to be a piece of a cadet barracks built in 1906 on the campus of Carlisle Military Academy, a private school that eventually became UTA. The Dallas Morning News originally covered the story, which was picked up by the Associated Press.

Veterans business fair

The Veterans Business Outreach Center at UTA will host a symposium and resource fair for veteran entrepreneurs, according to arlington-tx.gov. The symposium on Saturday, Nov. 18, will feature a free keynote lunch with Ashley and Andy Williams, the stars of HGTV’s “Flip or Flop Fort Worth.” The Williams are veterans-turned-entrepreneurs themselves.

Dance event

UTA’s Maverick Dance Company was featured in a city of Arlington Culture Buzz segment. The company’s formal concert, Via Dance, is scheduled for Dec. 8–10 at the UTA Fine Arts Building, 502 S. Cooper St., and will feature many different dance styles. 

Disney presentation

Ana Ramirez, a Disney Pixar sketch artist who worked on the new film “Coco,” shared some behind the scenes knowledge in a presentation on the UTA campus Tuesday. She spoke with WFAA ABC 8 about her journey from a child growing up in Guanajuato, Mexico, to landing a job at one of the world’s leading animation companies.

Future top student

The KRGV ABC 5 Student of the Week plans to attend UTA to major in nursing, the television station located in the Rio Grande Valley reported. Esmeralda Saldana is a top-ranked senior at Brownsville Lopez High School.

Alumnus joins real estate group

Kevin Douglas recently joined Southern Shores Real Estate Group, The Sommerville Journal Scene reported. Douglas earned his MBA from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, November 1, 2017
shortDescription: Approaching mega-cityAn opinion column in D Magazine about the future of commercial real estate agreed with UTA President Vistasp Karbhari’s assessmen
body:
Approaching mega-city

An opinion column in D Magazine about the future of commercial real estate agreed with UTA President Vistasp Karbhari’s assessment that the Dallas-Fort Worth metropolitan area will quickly achieve mega-city status. The column said Karbhari has been working to help the region prepare for this status. The column defines mega-cities as those surpassing 10 million residents. The DFW area now has about 7.1 million residents.

Online education

An Inside Higher Ed story asked whether instructors who teach online courses should also take online courses to gain experience. Peggy Semingson, assistant professor of curriculum and instruction in the College of Education, said that taking online certificate courses gave her a window into the minds of her students.

Small city aspects

In a recent ranking of the best small cities in America by WalletHub, Sanjiv Sabherwal, professor of finance and Distinguished Teaching Professor in the UTA College of Business, said quality of public schools and the cost-of-living index are important aspects to evaluate when considering living in a small city.

UAVs used to map

Research conducted at UTA using unmanned aerial vehicles could help cities save time and money after a natural disaster, WFAA ABC 8 reported. The project is currently focused on Beaumont, Texas as it continues to recover from Hurricane Harvey. KVUE ABC 24 in Austin also picked up the story. Anand Puppala, UTA associate dean for research and a civil engineering professor in the College of Engineering; Surya Congress, a civil engineering doctoral student; and Cody Lundberg, a research engineer at the UTA Research Institute are participating in the project.

ClaimBuster acclaim

A mediashift.org story about new fact-checking tools for media outlets mentioned ClaimBuster, a tool developed by Chengkai Li, UTA associate professor of computer science and engineering. ClaimBuster is part of the Tech & Check Cooperative, a new initiative launched by the Duke University Reporters’ Lab to automate fact-checking.

Middle East assistance

Brent Sasley, associate professor of political science in the College of Liberal Arts, was quoted in a Jewish Insider report about comments made to Congress by Nikki Haley, U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations, regarding economic assistance for the Middle East.

Transit study

Shima Hamidi, director of UTA’s Institute of Urban Studies and an assistant professor of urban planning in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, appeared on KDFW FOX 4 to discuss research conducted on Dallas Area Rapid Transit. Hamidi's research also was called a "landmark study" in a D Magazine article about DART's efforts to link transit riders with transit stops.

Toyota headquarters

From an architectural perspective, Toyota’s new Plano headquarters is lacking in inspiration. In a critique for The Dallas Morning News, Mark Lamster, professor in practice in UTA's College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, called the new space the equivalent of a Camry – "safe, but boring." Lamster is the newspaper’s architecture critic. 

Basketball teams' accolades

The UTA women’s basketball team received votes in the Top 25 USA Today preseason coaches’ poll. For the men's team, forward Kevin Hervey was named to the NBC Sports Preseason Mid-Major All-America Team. Guard Erick Neal made the honorable mention list.

Fouse named to board

Incyte Corp. named UTA alumna Jacqualyn Fouse to its board of directors, the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, streetinsider.com and many other media outlets reported. Fouse earned a bachelor and master of arts in economics and a doctorate in finance from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, November 3, 2017
shortDescription: Tax planRoger Meiners, chair of UTA’s Department of Economics and Goolsby Distinguished Professor of Economics and Law, provided analysis of the propo
body:
Tax plan

Roger Meiners, chair of UTA’s Department of Economics and Goolsby Distinguished Professor of Economics and Law, provided analysis of the proposed tax cut plan unveiled by the Republican party in a KXAS NBC 5 story. Meiners said average middle-class families would likely experience a slight decrease in taxes and the biggest change is a proposed reduction in corporate taxes.

Nurse licensing change

In a D CEO Healthcare column, Anne Bavier, dean of UTA’s College of Nursing and Health Innovation, praised a new initiative enabling Texas to join 25 states that have adopted an enhanced nurse licensure compact, which allows nurse licenses to be recognized across state lines. 

Iran nuclear deal letter

According to The New York Times and The Tehran Times, 90 experts in atomic sciences sent a letter to members of Congress encouraging them to take measures to preserve the Iran nuclear deal. David Nygren, UTA Presidential Distinguished Professor of Physics, was one of the experts who signed the letter.

Chemists on power list

Two chemists at The University of Texas at Arlington were named to Analytical Scientist Magazine’s 2017 Power List, according to Scienmag.com. Daniel Armstrong, the Robert A. Welch Distinguished Professor, and Purnendu “Sandy” Dasgupta, the Hamish Small Chair in Ion Analytics, are the only honorees from Texas universities to appear on the list.

Political analysis

Allan Saxe, associate professor of political science, offered analysis of the temporary suspension of President Donald Trump’s twitter account on WBAP 820 AM. In a separate WBAP 820 AM report, Saxe examined allegations of questionable agreements between the Democratic National Convention and Hillary Clinton made public in a new book by former DNC chair Donna Brazile.

UTA mentioned in district's growth

During a groundbreaking ceremony for the new Live! by Loews Hotel near Globe Life Park and AT&T Stadium, Arlington Mayor Jeff Williams said the new development will help the city grow its entertainment district from UTA to Interstate 30, The Dallas Morning News and KDFW FOX 4 reported.

Dia de Muertos

Isabel Montemayor, assistant professor of anthropology in UTA’s College of Liberal Arts, offered historical perspective on Dia de Muertos for KERA 90.1 FM’s Art & Seek program. Montemayor said the holiday is rooted in Mexican cultures in celebration and honor of loved ones who have died.

UTA Homecoming

Next week is Homecoming at UTA and businesses across Arlington are encouraged to show their Maverick pride, according to downtownarlington.org. The story includes a wrap up of the many spirit-filled events the general public is invited to attend. 

Veterans Day discussion

Kenyon Zimmer, associate professor of history in the College of Liberal Arts, will join a panel discussion about World War I at Tarleton State University during a commemoration of Veterans Day, reported the Stephenville Empire-Tribune.

Alumnus named vice president

A total of 25 years of food industry expertise and a degree in microbiology from UTA helped alumnus Robert Tyrell land a job as vice president of manufacturing with Litehouse Foods, according to delimarketnews.com. Litehouse produces salad dressings, dips and sauces.

New sales manager named

Andrew Wells, a UTA College of Business alumnus, is a new sales manager at Masaba Inc., a manufacturer of aggregate material handling solutions, according to americanrecycler.com.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, November 15, 2017
shortDescription: Future with robotsResearchers at UTA’s new Emotional Robotics Living Lab are investigating what the future will look like with robots. They're also ex
body:
Future with robots

Researchers at UTA’s new Emotional Robotics Living Lab are investigating what the future will look like with robots. They're also examining how robots can be integrated into the home to provide physical and emotional support, KTVT CBS 11, KRLD 1080 AM, ArlingtonTx.gov, CBSDFW.com, McKnight’s Senior Living, ScienMag and Phys.org reported. Julienne Greer, UTA assistant professor of Theatre Arts, is directing the new lab. 

Online course tips

Peggy Semingson, associate professor of curriculum and instruction in UTA's College of Education, and Catherine Spann, research scientist at UTA’s LINK Research Lab, were both featured in an Inside Higher Ed article giving advice on how to develop online courses. 

CAPPA symposium

UTA’s College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs and the Dallas Festival of Ideas are organizing a symposium 10 a.m. to 3:30 p.m. Saturday, Nov. 18, to evaluate strategies for Dallas’ historic Freedman’s Towns, self-sufficient communities founded by freed slaves after the end of the Civil War, H Urban reported. 

Award-winning architect

The Dallas Architecture Forum and UTA’s College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs are presenting a lecture by award-winning architect Fernando Tabuenca at 7 p.m. Tuesday, Nov. 14, at the Magnolia Theater in the West Village, Park Cities BubbleLife reported. 

UTA eSports

UTA’s eSports team was featured in an article about the rise of video game tournaments, the Dallas Observer reported. The story regaled the UTA team’s efforts in the Heroes of the Dorm tournament last spring but also told the story of eSports, which has evolved into a business that generated $696 million in revenue last year.

Rail connection questions

Arlington’s current contracts with the T and DART for one bus route between the UTA campus and the Trinity Railway Express Centreport Station, which will discontinue next month, was mentioned in a Dallas Morning News article about the proposed high-speed rail connection between Dallas and Fort Worth. Arlington’s position with respect to the high-speed project is unclear. 

Alumnus part of list

UTA alumnus and lawyer Kerry Braxton has been included in Marquis Who's Who, 24-7 reported. Mr. Braxton has achieved noteworthy prominence and a distinguished resume during his professional career, which includes notable tenures with Fortune 500 corporations, major financial institutions and a major international law firm. He earned a Bachelor of Arts degree from UTA. 

Gubernatorial appointee

UTA alumnus Elvira Reyna has been appointed to the Texas Commission on Public School Finance by Gov. Greg Abott, the Office of the Texas Governor  and Texas Thunder Radio reported. Reyna received a Bachelor of Arts in communications from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, November 10, 2017
shortDescription: Award for excellenceKevin Schug, the Shimadzu Distinguished Professor of Analytical Chemistry in the College of Science, received the 2017 J. Calvin G
body:
Award for excellence

Kevin Schug, the Shimadzu Distinguished Professor of Analytical Chemistry in the College of Science, received the 2017 J. Calvin Giddings Award for Excellence in Education, Life Plus Health and the New Brunswick Herald reported. The award recognizes scientists who enhance the personal and professional development of students in the field of analytical chemistry.

Facial recognition

Apple’s new facial recognition software is not fail proof, a WFAA ABC 8 story proved. Vassilis Athitsos, associate professor in UTA’s Computer Science and Engineering Department, explained how the technology uses millions of data points to learn what facial features to recognize.

Political analysis

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, rejected a Texas congressman’s attempt to force an impeachment vote on President Donald Trump before Christmas on KRLD 1080 AM, saying it was folly unless the Democrats gain control of the House. Saxe also analyzed Tuesday’s election results with KLIF 570 AM and WBAP 820 AM.

History in the making

The Fort Worth Star-Telegram predicted the upcoming UTA men’s basketball season could be the most successful in history. In a story titled, “Why you might want to get on the UTA hoops bandwagon now,” the paper said the Mavericks have all the parts in place to earn a bid to the NCAA tournament.

Climate resiliency

Nick Fang, UTA assistant professor of civil engineering, served on a climate-resilient infrastructure panel that discussed how well those structures fared following natural disasters, ASCE News reported. The panel was one of several featured at the American Society of Civil Engineers’ International Conference on Sustainable Infrastructure.

20 under 40

Max Kidd, associate director of technology for the UTA Police Department, was named to the “20 Under 40” class of 2017, compiled by Security Systems News. The list honors the next generation of security professionals leading the industry.

Alumna hired

The media landscape is changing, and new ideas and creative strategies are necessary to form extended reach into communities, according to The Westside Gazette, a newspaper in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., serving the African-American community. The newspaper hired UTA alumna Rochelle Davis-Cox as its new strategic marketing coordinator. 

Social worker honored

Anna Moulder Cloud, who earned a master of social work degree from UTA, received Howard Payne University’s Spirit of Social Work Award, reported KOXE 101.3 FM. According to the story, while at UTA, Cloud assisted with research on the evaluation of day care centers.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, February 7, 2018
shortDescription: Hispanic chamber chooses UTAThe United States Hispanic Chamber of Commerce Foundation chose UTA to lead a national initiative that will strengthen the
body:
Hispanic chamber chooses UTA

The United States Hispanic Chamber of Commerce Foundation chose UTA to lead a national initiative that will strengthen the college-to-career pipeline between Hispanic-Serving Institutions and corporations, reported The Dallas Morning News, Telemundo Amarillo, KCTV5.com in Kansas City, Public Radio International, and dozens of other outlets. Michele Bobadilla, UTA’s assistant provost for Hispanic student success and senior associate vice president for outreach services and community engagement, will chair the initiative. Troy Johnson, vice president of enrollment management, will act as an adviser.

Larger campaign contributions

In a column written for politicsofhope.com, Brent Boyea, UTA associate professor of political science, presented research findings demonstrating that states with professionalized court systems and partisan elections for judges see larger campaign contributions from individual donors. States with professionalized courts usually have judges with higher salaries, advanced resources, and freedom to determine their own agendas.

Sexual harassment

In an article published on the American Psychological Association’s apa.org, UTA’s James Campbell Quick called for more proactive involvement by companies and other institutions to reduce the prevalence of sexual harassment. Quick, Distinguished University Professor and John and Judy Goolsby-Jacqualyn A. Fouse Endowed Chair in UTA's Goolsby Leadership Academy, has researched sexual harassment for more than two decades. Quick’s recent publication in the Journal of Occupational Health Psychology with M. Ann McFadyen, associate professor of strategic management, was cited.

New UTA Dallas office

UTA is expanding its reach in Dallas with a new office that will help prospective students with the enrollment process, Al Día reported. The office, located at 1111 W. Mockingbird Dr., Suite 1180, celebrated its opening with an application drive that continues today.

National award winner

David Nygren’s selection as the 2018 Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers’ Marie Sklodowska-Curie Award recipient was mentioned in an article in The Institute, which recapped the year’s major awards. Nygren is a Presidential Distinguished Professor of Physics in UTA's College of Science. He is also a member of the National Academy of Sciences.

DACA help urged

Together with 20 Texas institutions including UTA, the Hispanic Association of Colleges and Universities sent a letter to Sen. John Cornyn, R-Texas, hacu.net reported. The letter urged the U.S. Senate to vote on the Dream Act before Feb. 8, the deadline to pass the next continuing resolution. 

Hervey potential draft pick

Senior Kevin Hervey, men’s basketball forward, was mentioned as a potential draft pick for the Dallas Mavericks in a SportsDayDFW.com story. Hervey is a good prospect, writer Eddie Sefko said. Sefko also said he’s a big fan of Hervey’s.

Alumna honored

UTA alumna Mae Jackson, the first African-American female mayor of Waco, Texas, was honored in a KWTX CBS 10 story commemorating Black History Month. Jackson earned a doctorate of philosophy from UTA. She died while in office.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, November 17, 2017
shortDescription: UTA dedicated to innovationUTA President Vistasp Karbhari was quoted in a Smart CEO article about The Rising Tide Initiative to empower entrepreneurs
body:
UTA dedicated to innovation

UTA President Vistasp Karbhari was quoted in a Smart CEO article about The Rising Tide Initiative to empower entrepreneurs in Fort Worth. “UTA is committed to developing an environment and culture that eliminates obstacles to innovation and entrepreneurship so that results of research and creative activity can be moved from our studios and laboratories into the economy for the benefit of society,” Karbhari said.

Sexual harassment article

James Campbell Quick, the John and Judy Goolsby-Jacqualyn A. Fouse Endowed Chair in the Goolsby Leadership Academy at UTA, co-authored a 2017 article "Sexual Harassment: Have We Made Any Progress?", that shows that women tend to report more adverse effects than men after experiencing workplace sexual harassment, ScienMag and Medical Xpress reported. The article was cited by the President of the American Psychological Association, who says that workplace sexual harassment is a chronic problem. 

Puppala profiled

Anand Puppala, UTA associate dean of research for the College of Engineering and civil engineering professor, was profiled in the September-October issue of TR News, a magazine the Transportation Research Board publishes. The TRB is one of seven major programs of the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine. Puppala, who also is director of UTA’s Sustainable and Resilient Civil Infrastructure Center, focused on major areas of his research, including sustainable utilization of recycled materials, expansive soils’ stabilization, resilience issues and use of drones to inspect infrastructure.

Charity credit cards

Abdul Rasheed, chair and Eunice and James L. West Distinguished Professor in the Department of Management in UTA's College of Business, gave his expert opinion on why there are few charity credit cards to WalletHub. “It is unclear whether this is necessarily an option that credit card holders want,” Rasheed said. “Redemption of rewards is a cost to the credit card issuer. Unredeemed rewards entail no cost to the credit card issuer. Thus, there is no incentive for them to do it.”

Leadership styles

David Mack, associate dean of UTA’s College of Business, was cited in a D Magazine article about the leadership styles of bankers like George Jones, who is launching CrossFirst Bank’s Dallas operations. “The wrong person with the right idea can be successful once or twice,” Mack said. 

Robotics lab

UTA’s new Emotional Robotics Living Lab continued to attract national attention with KTVT Fox 13 in Tampa, Fla., WALA Fox 10 in Mobile, Ala., Robotics Trends, Azorobotics and many other media outlets covering the start of the lab, which will investigate what the future will look like with robots.

New housing

Dallas-based Fountain Residential Partners has announced the development of its first student housing community in Arlington to serve UTA, WALB ABC 10 in Albany, Ga., and many other media outlets reported. Located on West Mitchell Street just west of Cooper Street, 8FOUR8 Mitchell will provide 298 luxury apartment homes for up to 687 students to serve the rapidly expanding UTA market.

Ride-share starts

Ride-share business Via has announced a partnership with the city of Arlington to provide on-demand ride sharing starting in December 2017, Planetizen reported. The Via service will replace the city's one existing bus line, called the Max, which runs one route connecting UTA with a transit center south of the Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport. 

NTC head retires

James Spaniolo, president and CEO of the North Texas Commission and former president of UTA, is retiring from the regional economic development organization, the Dallas Business Journal reported. The group will launch a search for a new leader, the article said.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, November 13, 2017
shortDescription: Facial recognitionVassilis Athitsos, UTA associate professor of computer science and engineering, was interviewed for a WFAA ABC 8 story about facial
body:
Facial recognition

Vassilis Athitsos, UTA associate professor of computer science and engineering, was interviewed for a WFAA ABC 8 story about facial recognition software on the new iPhone. He assured viewers that a “two-dimensional photo” should not be able to unlock the phone. The story also was aired on KREM CBS 2 in Spokane, Wash., WVEC ABC 13 in Norfolk, Va. and WFMY CBS 2 in Greensboro, N.C.

Brain stimulation

Hanli Liu, UTA bioengineering professor, is leading a multi-institutional Texas project to develop a new, non-invasive neuromodulation tool to enhance cognitive function in the human brain by using a technology called transcranial infrared brain stimulation, or TIBS, The Daily Texan reported. 

Helping telemedicine

A study by RadhaKanta Mahapatra, a professor in the Department of Information Systems and Operations Management in the UTA College of Business, highlights how micro-entrepreneurship can help to make the provision of telemedicine in such areas affordable and sustainable, DZone reported.

UTA teams win openers

UTA’s Kevin Hervey scored 28 points and his teammate Erick Neal hit three crucial 3-pointers to help fuel a second half rally and help the UTA men's team slip past Loyola Marymount for an 85-80 win in the season opener for both teams Saturday night, USA Today, the Star-Telegram and many other media reported. The Star-Telegram also reported that UTA's women's basketball team won Saturday, defeating Incarnate Word 61-48 in its home opener. Senior Rebekah VanDijk had a game-high 11 points and nine rebounds for UTA.

Politics book debuts

José Angel Gutiérrez, UTA professor emeritus in political science, has written a book about Chicana Severita Lara’s journey from being a migrant worker to mayor of her hometown, Crystal City, the Corpus Christi Caller-Times reported. The book is titled, “We won’t back down! Severita Lara’s rise from student leader to mayor.” 

UTA chemists honored

Two UTA chemists have been named among the top analytical scientists in the world by The Analytical Scientist magazine, Dallas Innovates reported. Daniel Armstrong and Purnendu “Sandy” Dasgupta were included in the magazine’s fifth annual Power List edition.

End User list

Max Kidd, associate director of technology in UTA Police Department, has been named an End User "20 under 40," Security Systems News reported. Kidd handles all the physical security in regards to cameras and intrusion. 

Campus Rec interview

Campus Rec Magazine asked Dax Kuykendall, UTA’s director of campus recreation, six questions about his role in campus recreation at the University.

Senate candidate

Democratic Congressman Beto O’Rourke of El Paso held a town hall meeting at UTA that attracted a standing room only crowd of 300 people inside a lecture hall, CBS DFW.com reported. O’Rourke is challenging Republican incumbent Ted Cruz for a seat in the U.S. Senate. 

Homecoming featured

UTA’s Homecoming Celebration was featured on the Arlington Voice website, which included a schedule of Saturday’s events, including the 7 p.m. basketball game with the Maverick men's basketball team taking on the Loyola Marymount Lions.

Students want Max bus

Some UTA students are resisting the Arlington City Council’s decision to end the Max bus service for an alternative rideshare service called Via, which goes live Dec. 11, KXAX NBC 5 reported. "We're dependent on this," UTA Senior Yolanda Easley said. "We are coming from Plano, Richardson, Carrollton, Farmers Branch, Mesquite and this is the only bus Arlington has."

Dreamers demonstrate

Some UTA students, including Linda Rivas of Mavericks United UTA, demonstrated outside the offices of Republican Sen. John Cornyn to request support for the Dream Act to create a permanent solution for undocumented youths, Mundo Hispanico reported. 

Veterans Day memories

Shawn Mathiews, a UTA alumnus, Huntsville High School assistant athletic trainer and veteran, was interviewed in the Cleburne Times and Mineral Wells Index on Veteran’s Day about how he joined the army, where he worked as a medic specializing as a physical therapy technician. He earned his bachelor’s degree at UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, November 20, 2017
shortDescription: Harassment studiedSexual harassment in the workplace is a chronic problem that can cause enduring psychological harm, according to the American Psycho
body:
Harassment studied

Sexual harassment in the workplace is a chronic problem that can cause enduring psychological harm, according to the American Psychological Association. A report on the association’s website referenced a 2017 article on the topic written by Jim Quick, Distinguished University Professor and John and Judy Goolsby–Jacqualyn A. Fouse Endowed Chair in the Goolsby Leadership Academy. The article was co-written by M. Ann McFadyen, associate professor of strategic management in UTA’s College of Business.

Research on robots

Research conducted by Julienne Greer, UTA assistant professor of theatre arts, attracted additional coverage, with KXAS NBC 5 reporting on Greer’s new Emotional Robotics Living Lab. Greer’s research about the interaction of humans and robots showed that interacting with robots decreased depression among senior citizens.

Maverick Theatre Company

BroadwayWorld.com reported on the performance of Shakespeare’s A Midsummer Night’s Dream presented by the Maverick Theatre Company over the weekend on the UTA campus. The website called the cast friendly and hard-working. 

Mavericks win

UTA’s men’s basketball team coasted to an 89-75 win over BYU, The Dallas Morning News, Washington Post, Mid-Major Madness and many other media reported. The Salt Lake Tribune wrote that UTA should consider playing more games in the Marriott Center in Provo, Utah, as Saturday’s victory marked the Mavs’ second win there in eight months.

Lady Mavs victorious

The Lady Mavs topped SMU on Sunday by hitting a three pointer with just seconds to go, reported The Star-Telegram. The team plays again Friday afternoon.

Alumnus named to board

Wes Blair, UTA alumnus and Cape Girardeau, Mo. police chief, was named to the Child Abuse and Neglect Review Board by Gov. Eric Greitens, STL News reported. Blair earned a bachelor’s degree in organizational leadership and a master’s degree in public administration from UTA.

Alumnus wins half marathon

UTA alumnus Craig Lautenslager won the New Zealand half marathon in 1 hour 4 minutes and 58 seconds, reported the Nelson Mail. Lautenslager’s time is the fifth fastest winning time in the history of the New Zealand half marathon. Lautenslager, a former track athlete at UTA, graduated in May with a degree in computer science.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, November 29, 2017
shortDescription: RNA biomarkersUTA researchers have published a review on the potential use of long non-coding RNA as biomarkers for cancer and for novel gene therapie
body:
RNA biomarkers

UTA researchers have published a review on the potential use of long non-coding RNA as biomarkers for cancer and for novel gene therapies, MILTECH reported. Subhrangsu Mandal, UTA associate professor of chemistry and biochemistry and lead author of the study, said that though the field is still in its infancy, researchers are also looking at using long non-coding RNA to predict cancer prognosis and patient outcomes.

Foreign student enrollment

UTA’s total enrollment has increased but the number of foreign students is down by more than 400 students, KERA 90.1 FM reported in a story about overall international enrollment in higher ed. Troy Johnson, UTA vice president for enrollment management, was quoted in the article. KUHF 88.7 FM, Houston’s public radio station, also covered the story.

Emerging Leader

LCGC announced that Zachary Breitbach, a former UTA research scientist, has won the 2018 Emerging Leader Award, Chromotographyonline.com reported. Breitbach also earned his doctorate from UTA. Currently, he is a senior scientist at AbbVie.

Ridesharing service

Since 2013, the city of Arlington’s mass transit system was a single bus route that was used mainly by UTA students, Dallas Innovates reported. Earlier this month, the Arlington City Council voted to end the route, and replace it with the ridesharing service Via beginning Dec. 11.

Transit deserts

Diane Jones Allen, program director of landscape architecture at UTA’s College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, wrote a column about the evolution of transit deserts and how to achieve transit equity and mobility for Metro, a magazine for the transit and motorcoach industry.

Animation award

UTA broadcast student Casey Moore won the Animation Excellence Prize in the Texas Central contest for short film competition to illustrate the state’s proposed bullet train, KBTX CBS 3 in Bryan, Texas, reported. The title of Moore’s animation entry is “Me, Myself, The Guy.” The competition drew 45 proposals. Students from UTA and Texas A&M took the top prizes.

Origami-like method

Researchers from the University of Wisconsin-Madison and UTA developed an origami-like method of creating deeply bowl- or dome-shaped silicon detectors, Laser Focus World reported.

New president

Emir Caner has been named president of Georgia’s Truett McConnell University, The Chattanoogan reported. Caner earned his doctorate in philosophy from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, November 22, 2017
shortDescription: Best for military vetsUTA is the best four-year university in Texas for veterans and their families, reported CBSDFW.com. The report referred to ranki
body:
Best for military vets

UTA is the best four-year university in Texas for veterans and their families, reported CBSDFW.com. The report referred to rankings released by the Military Times on Monday listing UTA as the No. 1 four-year university in Texas and No. 12 in the nation for veterans and their families to earn a college degree.

Contaminated groundwater

Three new research studies from UTA have found harmful pathogenic bacteria in groundwater near unconventional natural gas extraction sites in Texas, Phys.org and Infection Control Today reported. “Our latest published research has revealed that harmful bacteria can be quite prevalent in Texas groundwater, especially waters that contain various chemical contaminants,” said Kevin Schug, Shimadzu Distinguished Professor of Analytical Chemistry and director of UTA’s Collaborative Laboratories for Environmental Analysis and Remediation, or CLEAR, Lab. 

Living lab

The Dallas Morning News, Dallas Innovates, ASEE First Bell, China's Irobotnews and France's Infohightech reported on the opening of UTA’s Emotional Robotics Living Lab, which aims to investigate what our future will look like with robots. Julienne Greer, UTA assistant professor of theatre arts, is director of the new lab.

Sexual harassment

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, analyzed the recent high-profile sexual harassment cases involving politicians and other powerful men on WBAP 820 AM and KLIF 570 AM.

Bike sharing

UTA has requested that bike sharing company Ofo remove its bikes from campus, KDFW Fox 4 reported. While Ofo has an agreement with the City of Arlington, UTA has a bike sharing agreement with Zagster. 

Social media confusion

After serial killer Charles Manson died, some confused social media users began to memorialize musician Marilyn Manson instead. WBAP 820 AM asked UTA social media coordinator Hillary Green to analyze the situation. Green said in a rush to be the first to post an opinion online, people sometimes forget to check all of the facts.

Mavs gaining respect

The UTA men’s basketball team took one of the top 25 teams in the nation down to the wire. The Mavericks fell to the University of Alabama in Tuscaloosa last night by a score of 77-76, and ESPNU called UTA one of the best mid-majors in the country.

New development

Dallas-based development firm Fountain Residential Partners LLC is teaming up with HC2 Capital LLC to build its first student housing community near The University of Texas at Arlington, Dallas Business Journal, Student Housing Business and Rebusiness Online reported. The 298-unit apartment community is now under construction near West Mitchell and South Cooper Streets.

On-demand rides

Arlington’s partnership with Via, a New York–based startup that offers on-demand minibus rides to replace the Max, the single, fixed-route bus line that ran between UTA and a commuter rail station near DFW Airport, was featured in The Atlantic and Citylab. UTA students dependent on the Max have voiced concern that not enough people share the same schedules to make an on-demand service truly convenient.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, February 5, 2018
shortDescription: #MeToo series articleJames Campbell Quick, Distinguished University Professor and John and Judy Goolsby-Jacqualyn A. Fouse Endowed Chair in UTA's Gool
body:
#MeToo series article

James Campbell Quick, Distinguished University Professor and John and Judy Goolsby-Jacqualyn A. Fouse Endowed Chair in UTA's Goolsby Leadership Academy, and Ann McFadyen, associate professor of strategic management in the College of Business, co-authored an article for Harvard Business Review as part of the publication’s “Managing #MeToo” series. The article by Quick and McFadyen presents a three-stage approach to preventing sexual harassment in the workplace and offers suggestions for companies about how and when to intervene.

Super Bowl ad class

Students in UTA associate marketing professor Traci Freling’s class spent Super Bowl Sunday paying as much attention to the commercials as the game, The Dallas Morning News reported. Freling last week showed her students several blockbuster ads from previous years and then instructed them to closely watch Sunday’s ads. This week, they will discuss which ads they felt were most and least effective.

REHEAL glove

Manufacturing of the REHEAL glove is moving closer to reality, according to Dallas Innovates. The glove was developed by UTA’s Research Institute. Muthu Wijesundara, UTARI's chief research scientist, received a grant from the Medical Technology Enterprise Consortium to help with commercialization of the glove.

Classroom technology

Stephanie Cole, an associate professor of history in UTA’s College of Liberal Arts, uses technology during her lectures to increase engagement and identify students who are struggling and not participating, according to Inside Higher Ed. The story focuses on the Echo360 technology, which allows students to give real time feedback to professors.

Point guard enters record book

Erick Neal became the first player in Sun Belt Conference history to surpass 1,300 points, 700 assists, 400 rebounds and 200 steals during Saturday’s victory over Coastal Carolina, Fox Sports and the Austin American-Statesman reported. Davion Turner scored a career-high 20 points and Johnny Hamilton had his fifth double-double of the year. The Lady Mavericks also defeated Coastal Carolina on Saturday, thanks in large part to senior Shelby Richards’s career-high 20 points.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, April 30, 2018
shortDescription: Materials grantsAndrew Makeev, a UTA aerospace engineering professor, has received two Office of Naval Research grants worth nearly $1.5 million that
body:
Materials grants

Andrew Makeev, a UTA aerospace engineering professor, has received two Office of Naval Research grants worth nearly $1.5 million that will further enhance the Advanced Materials and Structures Lab’s national standing and capabilities, U.S. Fed News and Brinkwire.com reported. Makeev also is the AMSL director.

Fellowship awarded

Marquerite Herzog, a UTA biology doctoral student, has been awarded a prestigious National Science Foundation Graduate Research Fellowship to study the molecular genetic basis of changes in behavior seen when an individual loses during an aggressive conflict, U.S. Fed News reported.

Science in the City

Alice Lubbe, a UTA mathematics professor, spent the morning of her 52nd birthday at UT Southwestern Medical Center as a participant in Science in the City, The Dallas Morning News reported. Lubbe was fascinated by the slices of a human brain, and seeing firsthand how Alzheimer's disease can shrink the brain to about half its size. 

Alumna recognized

Jeanette Davidson was recognized in “Diverse: Issues in Higher Education” magazine as one of its top 25 women in higher education, OUDaily.com reported. Davidson earned her master’s degree in social work at UTA. 

Old Chevy El Camino

Ragenna Prince, UTA's director of facilities services, gives her thoughts on being the lucky one to drive the school’s 1983 Chevrolet El Camino, Star-Telegram reported. 

Alumnus dies

UTA alum William Howard Garrett, known to family as “Ted” and to friends as “Bill,” died Friday in his home in Little Elm, Texas, at the age of 74, Roswell Daily Record reported. Garrett earned his bachelor’s degree in accounting with high honors in 1971 and was a certified public accountant for Price Waterhouse in Houston for many years.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, November 27, 2017
shortDescription: Best for military vetsCarlos Iglesias, UTA junior and army veteran, was featured in a KXTX Telemundo 39 report about veterans. The story referenced UT
body:
Best for military vets

Carlos Iglesias, UTA junior and army veteran, was featured in a KXTX Telemundo 39 report about veterans. The story referenced UTA’s diversity and recent ranking by the Military Times as the No. 1 four-year university in Texas for veterans and their families to earn a college degree.

Robotics living lab

The Star-Telegram reported on the opening of UTA’s Emotional Robotics Living Lab, which aims to investigate what our future will look like with robots. Julienne Greer, UTA assistant professor of theatre arts, is director of the new lab.

New film

Patty Newton, a UTA film instructor, filmed City Hearts over six months in Grand Prairie, The Dallas Morning News reported. The film is about a group of 10 former inmates joining local artists to create a public art exhibit.

Groundwater research

Kevin Schug, Shimadzu Distinguished Professor of Analytical Chemistry and director of UTA’s Collaborative Laboratories for Environmental Analysis and Remediation, or CLEAR, explained to KUHF 88.7 FM that UTA research studies found some harmful pathogenic bacteria in groundwater near unconventional natural gas extraction sites in Texas. Science Newsline, Lab Manager Magazine and NGI Shale Daily also had articles about the UTA studies. Energy Wire interviewed Zac Hildenbrand, chief scientific officer at Inform Environmental LLC, major contributor to UTA’s CLEAR and one of the researchers in the studies.

Workplace harassment

Sexual harassment in the workplace is a chronic problem that can cause enduring psychological harm, MedicalXpress reported. A report on the American Psychological Association website referenced a 2017 article on the topic written by Jim Quick, Distinguished University Professor and John and Judy Goolsby–Jacqualyn A. Fouse Endowed Chair in the Goolsby Leadership Academy. The article was co-written by M. Ann McFadyen, associate professor of strategic management in UTA’s College of Business.

Winning streak

The UTA men’s basketball team won the Barclay’s Center Classic regional title with a 95-90 win over Niagara, the Star-Telegram, USA Today, the Fresno, Calif., Bee, the Austin American-Statesman, KXAS NBC 5, WIBV CBS 4 in Buffalo, N.Y. and many other media outlets reported. Point guard Erick Neal was named the tournament's most valuable player. The UTA women’s team is 5-0 and most recently defeated Fresno State 67-54, the Star-Telegram reported.

Giving thanks

Harvest Moon, UTA adjunct lecturer in sociology, wrote a Thanksgiving letter to her students which was published in Inside Higher Ed. Moon told her students their ability to envision the world as it could be is inspiring.

Bilingual educators

Grand Prairie ISD has partnered with The University of Texas at Arlington to offer high school juniors and seniors dual-credit opportunities that also put them on an accelerated path toward becoming bilingual teachers, The Dallas Morning News and Texas Ed Equity blog reported. The story analyzed how Texas could end its bilingual teacher shortage.

Upscale living

Fountain Residential, which is building an upscale student housing complex near the UTA campus, was one of the companies mentioned in a Dallas Morning News story about the increasing amenities arms race in university living. Fountain Residential's latest project is located near West Mitchell and South Cooper Streets.

Political scandal

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, does not believe the latest controversy surrounding U.S. Rep. Joe Barton, R-Ennis, will derail the congressman’s political career, The Washington Post reported. Saxe also analyzed sexual harassment and assault, North Korea and Roy Moore staying in the Alabama senatorial race on WBAP 820 AM over the holiday weekend.

Alumnus profiled

Keith Downey was featured in a Houston Chronicle story about his non-profit, charitable work. Downey is a UTA alumnus.

MOOCs listed

Quartz reported that 200 universities just launched 600 free online courses. Eight of UTA’s Massive Open Online Courses or MOOCs were included in the list.

Generous alumnus

Earl and Nancy McCuin, who both attended Ouachita Baptist University, left OBU a $1.39 million donation for student scholarships, the Arkansas Democrat-Gazette reported. Earl McCuin earned his master’s degree in social work from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, May 2, 2018
shortDescription: Piper professorDavid Hullender, a longtime UTA professor of mechanical and aerospace engineering, has been named a 2018 Piper Professor by the San Ant
body:
Piper professor

David Hullender, a longtime UTA professor of mechanical and aerospace engineering, has been named a 2018 Piper Professor by the San Antonio-based Minnie Stevens Piper Foundation, Phys.org reported. 

New business dean

Harry Dombroski, a longtime Hunt Consolidated and Hunt Oil Co. executive, has been appointed dean of The University of Texas at Arlington College of Business, Dallas Morning News reported. 

PhD student earns fellowship

Marquerite Herzog, a UTA biology doctoral student, has been awarded a prestigious National Science Foundation Graduate Research Fellowship to study the molecular genetic basis of changes in behavior seen when an individual loses during an aggressive conflict, Phys.org reported. 

Water technologies

UTA-led research is leading to new technologies that will make water fracking procedures more eco-friendly, CBS 11 DFW reported. The research is being done in the Collaborative Laboraties for Environmental Analysis and Remediation in partnership with Challenger Water Technologies under the direction of Kevin Schug, a UTA associate professor in the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry. 

Lab expansion, partnership

Two UTA researchers at the Collaborative Laboratories for Environmental Analysis and Remediation, Zacariah Hildenbrand and Kevin Schug, wrote a column in Science Trends regarding the lab's recent expansion and partnership with oil field equipment supplier Challenger Water Solutions to develop water recycling technologies and how they’re making the most out of produced oilfield waste. 

Chawla remembered

UTA alumna and astronaut Kalpana Chawla, the first woman of Indian origin in space, was remembered by President Donald Trump on Monday for her contributions to NASA after issuing an official directive announcing the month of May as Asian American and Pacific Islander Heritage Month, International Business Times reported. Chawla earned her master’s in aerospace engineering from UTA in 1982. 

Cured pipes study

UTA researchers at the Center for Underground Infrastructure Research and Education and the Institute for Underground Infrastructure in Germany find existing literature on chemical emissions of styrenated cured-in-place pipes non-conclusive, Trenchless Technology reported. 

Sustainable goals

UTA recently signed on to the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals and is leading an inclusive regional effort to apply for UN designation as a regional center of excellence, EatGreenDFW reported. 

Alumni run small company

UTA alumni and brothers, Tom Le and Kevin Le, run a small company, Luraco Massage Chairs, that has made a name for itself by being the only company manufacturing 100 percent of its products in the United States, CEPro.com reported. Tom earned a master's degree in electrical engineering and Kevin earned a doctorate in electrical engineering from UTA. 

Best nursing

Amber Bellcock was nominated as one of the area’s best nurses by Todd Nighswonger, a senior media relations and communications specialist at Mercy Hospital Fort Smith in Fort Smith, Ark., the Times Record reported. Bellcock earned her master’s degree in nursing from UTA. 

Vinylthon event

Lance Liguez, UTA Radio faculty adviser and president of College Radio Day, talked about Vinylthon, an event encouraging college radio stations to play vinyl records and drum up new listeners to the old format, College Media Matters reported.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, May 4, 2018
shortDescription: New bio-printing hydrogelYi Hong, a UTA bioengineering professor and his team of researchers, have developed a highly elastic biodegradable hydrogel f
body:
New bio-printing hydrogel

Yi Hong, a UTA bioengineering professor and his team of researchers, have developed a highly elastic biodegradable hydrogel for bio-printing of materials that mimic natural human soft tissues, SICCAS or the Shanghai Institute of Ceramics of the Chinese Academy of Sciences and Medicine News Line reported. Bio-printing uses live cells within the scaffolding of the new tissues and could potentially transform cell printing. 

Link between hormones, cholesterol

Subhrangsu Mandal, UTA associate professor of chemistry and biochemistry, and a team of researchers are investigating the link between ovarian hormones and the blood cholesterol balance in the body, a key determinant of cardiovascular health or disease, Phys.org, News Medical Life Science, Brinkwire, Infosurhoy.com and other media outlets reported. 

CLEAR partnership

UTA’s Collaborative Laboratories for Environmental Analysis and Remediation has expanded its partnership with oil field equipment supplier Challenger Water Solutions to develop water recycling technologies that will transform waste from unconventional oil and gas development into reusable water, ASEE's First Bell and KTVT CBS 11 reported. ASEE is the American Society of Engineering Education.

District award

Myron Pullum, UTA veteran’s business adviser at the Veterans Business Outreach Center in the College of Business, was awarded this year's 2018 DFW District Veteran Business Champion of the Year Award from U.S. Small Business Administration, Thai News Service reported. 

Tough determination

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, offered his opinion on labeling millennial students as liberals, KTRH 740 AM reported. Saxe talked about how politics is confusing these days and it’s difficult for almost anyone to figure it all out. 

Data policy laws

Justin Dellinger, UTA associate director of the LINK Research Lab, talked about the strict laws forcing companies and colleges around the globe to re-evaluate their data policies and practices, EdSurge.com reported. In less than three weeks, the strict privacy regulations will go into effect for the European Union. Dellinger teaches a MOOC on Learning Analytics Fundamentals on edX.

UTA senior helps organize

Waed Alhayek, UTA senior and executive director of StudentsMarch.org, is organizing a counter-protest rally one street away from the convention center where NRA members will listen to President Trump deliver a message to them, The Guardian reported. 

Alumna running for governor

Lupe Valdez, former Dallas County sheriff and a candidate for Governor of Texas in the 2018 gubernatorial election, was profiled in a USA Today Network story that the Corpus Christi Caller Times ran. Valdez earned a master’s degree in criminal justice from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, December 15, 2017
shortDescription: Improving pathwaysIn a column for Evolllution.com, UTA President Vistasp Karbhari challenged four-year universities and community colleges to work tog
body:
Improving pathways

In a column for Evolllution.com, UTA President Vistasp Karbhari challenged four-year universities and community colleges to work together to improve transferability. “We have no option except to put aside differences, break down silos, forget artificial spheres of influence and work in integrated fashion, putting the success of students first,” Karbhari wrote.

UTA and Pattie LaBelle

UTA faculty, students and alumni who appear on legendary entertainer Patti LaBelle’s holiday album performed live on WFAA ABC 8 this morning in multiple segments. A story featuring Dan Cavanagh, director of UTA’s music industry studies program and associate professor of music; Jamar Jones, lecturer of music industry studies; and student Caleb Moore also aired on KXAS NBC 5. Additionally, Jones discussed UTA’s involvement with LaBelle's album on KRLD 1080 AM.

Emotional robotics

Julienne Greer, assistant professor of theatre arts in UTA’s College of Liberal Arts, appeared on KERA 90.1 FM discussing her research in the field of social and emotional robotics. She found that interactions with robots had a positive impact on the lives of senior citizens in an assisted living facility. Greer is the director of UTA’s new Emotional Robotics Living Lab.

Political insight

Allan Saxe, assistant professor of political science, provided commentary on the outcome of the Alabama senate race on WGST 640 AM in Atlanta. In The Dallas Morning News, Saxe offered insight on former KXAS NBC 5 anchor Mike Snyder announcing a run for Tarrant County Tax Assessor.

Professor honored

Krishnan Rajeshwar, Distinguished Professor of chemistry and biochemistry in UTA's College of Science, received a Doctor Honoris Causa degree from the University of Szeged in Hungary, reported publicnow.com.

Restoration needed

Dallas’s Kalita Humphreys Theater, an iconic work by architect Frank Lloyd Wright, needs to restored, wrote Mark Lamster, associate professor in practice in UTA’s College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, and architecture critic of The Dallas Morning News. Lamster said no other building in Dallas has been as mistreated, misused or mismanaged.

Concert scheduled

Members of UTA’s horn choir, along with several professional musicians, will accompany more than 100 French horn students from Grapevine-Colleyville ISD, Keller ISD and other schools in concert tonight, according to communityimpact.com. 

Principal hired

Chris Chappotin was named principal of Burleson’s STEAM Middle School of Choice, reported the Cleburne Times Review. Chappotin earned a master’s degree in educational leadership and policy studies from UTA.

Alumnus opens law firm

Mark Haney announced the opening of Puls Haney Kaiser PLLC, a new law firm in Austin, according to Attorney at Law Magazine. Haney, past president and board member of the Tarrant County Trial Lawyers Association, earned a bachelor’s degree from UTA in 1983.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, December 8, 2017
shortDescription: Running for governorA graduate of The University of Texas at Arlington officially announced a run for Texas governor, reported KTVT CBS 11, The Texas
body:
Running for governor

A graduate of The University of Texas at Arlington officially announced a run for Texas governor, reported KTVT CBS 11, The Texas Tribune, the Star-Telegram, and many other Texas media outlets. Dallas County Sheriff Lupe Valdez earned a master of arts in criminology and criminal justice from UTA. She joins a crowded field of democrats challenging Gov. Greg Abbott in 2018.

Research featured

The International Business Times reported on research conducted by Jim C. Quick and Ann McFadyen about sexual harassment in the workplace. Quick is the Distinguished University Professor and John and Judy Goolsby – Jacqualyn A. Fouse Endowed Chair in the Goolsby Leadership Academy. McFadyen is an associate professor of strategic management in UTA’s College of Business. Their research was also featured in the Business Herald.

Middle east analysis

Brent Sasley, associate professor of political science in the College of Liberal Arts, provided live analysis of President Trump’s decision to recognize Jerusalem as the capital of Israel on KLIF 570 AM. Sasley said because the move was made unilaterally, the power of the United States to broker a peace deal could be weakened.

Housing and transportation

A UTA study researching affordable transportation and housing in the Dallas-Fort Worth metroplex shows the area has a lack of both, according to KRLD 1080 AM. Shima Hamidi, director of UTA’s Institute of Urban Studies and an assistant professor of urban planning in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, said low income families across North Texas are forced to spend a disproportionate amount of their income on transportation.

Political insight

Allan Saxe, associate professor of political science in UTA's College of Liberal Arts, provided insight on the resignation of U.S. Senator Al Franken, D-Minnesota, on WGST 640 AM. Saxe also analyzed the change in U.S. policy recognizing Jerusalem as the capital of Israel and the decision to run for Texas governor by Dallas County Sheriff Lupe Valdez on KLIF 570 AM. 

Ethics policy

Students from UTA’s College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs helped the city of Mineral Wells draft a formal ethics policy, reported the Cleburne Times Review. The students presented the draft at a city council meeting this week after collaborating with Mineral Wells’ Finance Director John Moran, a UTA graduate.

Tax plan opposition

Enid Arvidson, UTA associate professor of planning and public affairs, was among 200 public policy and economics professors who wrote an open letter to Congress opposing tax plans approved by both houses, according to blackstarnews.com.

Textbook published

Phys.org reported that Kevin Schug, Shimadzu Distinguished Professor of Analytical Chemistry and director of UTA’s Collaborative Laboratories for Environmental Analysis and Remediation, and Zacariah Hildenbrand, major contributor to CLEAR, edited one publication in a group of several new textbooks from global publishing company Elsevier.

Culture of care

Establishing a culture of care can do a lot for nurturing a professional environment for nurses, the Alvin Sun & Advertiser in Alvin, Texas, and the Alliance Times-Herald in Alliance, Neb., reported. The article quoted Anne Bavier, National League for Nursing president and dean of UTA's College of Nursing and Health Innovation.

Alumna re-elected

Theresa Kyzar, Northwestern State University assistant professor of nursing, was recently re-elected as the North America Regional Coordinator for Sigma Theta Tau International, the second-largest nursing organization in the world, PublicNow.com reported. Kyzar is a graduate of UTA.

Law firm hires alumna

Rachael Wood earned a bachelor’s degree from UTA’s criminology and criminal justice program before becoming an attorney. Wood will join the Clearwater, Fla., offices of Johnson, Pope, Bokor, Ruppe,l & Burns LLP, according to tampabaynewswire.com.

Alumna joins health provider

Caitlin Branham is joining Mind Springs Health in Grand Junction, Colo., to provide mental health services, reported The Business Times. Branham earned a master’s degree from UTA’s College of Nursing and Health Innovation.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, February 9, 2018
shortDescription: New partnershipUTA announced a new partnership with Revature, the Houston Chronicle, Seattle Post-Intelligencer, mysanantonio.com and dozens of other
body:
New partnership

UTA announced a new partnership with Revature, the Houston Chronicle, Seattle Post-Intelligencer, mysanantonio.com and dozens of other media outlets reported. Revature, a technology talent development company, will provide students and recent graduates access to hands-on training programs to help them land jobs in the growing field of software engineering.

College-to-career initiative

UTA was selected by the United States Hispanic Chamber of Commerce Foundation to lead a national college-to-career initiative, KTVT CBS 11 and Fort Worth Business Press reported. The goal of the initiative, known as University Partnerships, is to pair corporations with universities to increase the number of paid internship opportunities for students. 

Love Field study

The Dallas Morning News reported on UTA’s study of a potential redesign of the north entrance to Dallas Love Field. The article focused on the future of Bachman Lake. Shima Hamidi, director of the Institute of Urban Studies in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, is leading the Love Field study.

Campaign financing

Allan Saxe, associate professor of political science in UTA’s College of Liberal Arts, offered analysis of campaign fundraising by Democrats and Republicans in Texas’ congressional races in the Cleburne Times Review, Athens Review and Corsicana Daily Sun. Saxe said money is an indication of candidate’s strength.

Award winner

Somayeh Moazzeni, a UTA doctoral student in public policy and transportation, received a national award, Phys.org reported. Moazzeni was recognized by the U.S. Department of Transportation as the 2017 outstanding student of the year for the UTA-based Center for Transportation, Equity, Decisions and Dollars.

New face

Maria Frias, a senior civil engineering student at UTA, was named one of the New Faces of Civil Engineering, Collegiate Edition, Techsite reported. The New Faces of Civil Engineering list is produced by the American Society of Civil Engineers or ASCE.

Veteran's life

The life story of AJ Czubai, a UTA civil engineering senior and marine corps veteran, is the focus of a two-person play and multimedia production called BASETRACK, which hundreds of soldiers at Fort Hood attended, the Fort Hood Sentinel reported. The production, which has toured across the United States, focuses on Czubai and his wife as they try to readjust to life after he returns from Afghanistan.

Alumnus releases album

Matthew McNeal, Fort Worth singer-songwriter and UTA alumnus, is releasing a new album that blends Americana, indie rock, soul, gospel and funk, Fort Worth Weekly reported. McNeal graduated with a degree in business marketing in 2014.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, December 18, 2017
shortDescription: Survivor's taleWhen Annie Kendzior graduated from UTA’s College of Business with her MBA on Saturday, it marked a major milestone in the sexual assaul
body:
Survivor's tale

When Annie Kendzior graduated from UTA’s College of Business with her MBA on Saturday, it marked a major milestone in the sexual assault survivor’s life, KXAS NBC 5 reported. Kendzior said she hopes her accomplishments show other survivors what is possible if they speak up and refuse to give up. New England Cable News also ran the story.

Communications improvements

Breakthrough research conducted by a team from UTA and the University of Vermont could lead to a dramatic reduction in the cost and energy consumption of high-speed internet communications, International Business Times, India Today, Innovation Toronto, Science Daily and phys.org reported. Michael Vasilyev, a UTA electrical engineering professor, developed an optical medium in which multiple beams of light can autocorrect their own properties without affecting other beams. 

Soil sensor patent

Anand Puppala, UTA associate dean for research in the College of Engineering and a civil engineering professor, recently was awarded a patent for an integrated sensor and algorithm that will expedite the assessment of soil near bridges and roads, scienmag.com and Techsite reported.

Quick quoted

In a Des Moines Register article about a poll finding 40 percent of Iowa women have experienced sexual harassment, James Quick said women previously weren’t comfortable reporting incidents, but a change in attitudes will help provide researchers more accurate data about the issue. Quick is Distinguished University Professor and John and Judy Goolsby–Jacqualyn A. Fouse Endowed Chair in the Goolsby Leadership Academy in UTA’s College of Business.

Name recognition payoff

Allan Saxe, a UTA associate professor of political science in the College of Liberal Arts, offered insight in a Dallas Morning News column about former WFAA ABC 8 investigative reporter Brett Shipp and former KXAS NBC 5 anchor Mike Snyder running for public office. Saxe said the name recognition Shipp and Snyder have is “worth a million dollars.”

UTA choral program noted

The University of Texas at Arlington has an “excellent choral program,” reported The Dallas Morning News in a review of recent holiday performances from two of Dallas’s premiere singing groups. The story says UTA adds to the strength of the region’s culture of singing.

Lifetime award

Mary Lynne Crow, a professor in the department of curriculum and instruction in UTA’s College of Education, was presented with the Albert Nelson Marquis Lifetime Achievement Award by the Marquis Who’s Who, nbherard.com reported.

Alumna recognized

District Administration magazine recognized Lauren Benner, a second-grade teacher in Midlothian, for her innovative skills of incorporating electronics with reading and writing in the classroom, the Midlothian Mirror reported. Benner earned her master’s degree from UTA.

Alumnus elected to board

Steve Drucker was elected to the Farmers Trust & Savings Bank board of directors in Spencer, Iowa, the Spencer Daily Reporter reported. Drucker earned a master’s degree from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, February 12, 2018
shortDescription: Record enrollmentUTA’s spring enrollment reached a milestone yet again, U.S. Fed News reported. With almost 43,000 students this semester, the univers
body:
Record enrollment

UTA’s spring enrollment reached a milestone yet again, U.S. Fed News reported. With almost 43,000 students this semester, the university experienced a 2.4 percent increase in enrollment over last spring. The College of Nursing and Health Innovation, the School of Social Work and the College of Business saw notable increases.

Young fundraisers

Caragh Christie, a 5-year-old who has started drawing pictures and selling them to benefit people in need, was featured on a KXAS NBC 5 story about a fundraiser last week at a Mansfield toy store. Christie is the daughter of Michael Magnus, a UTA communication lecturer. This fundraiser helped Little Hands Book Bank, a non-profit started by Jamison Hands, whose mom is Jennifer Little, another UTA communication lecturer. Little Hands Book Bank helps provide books for children who don’t have easy access to books. The event raised about $300.

Hervey makes history

Kevin Hervey, a senior forward, became UTA’s all-time career leader in rebounds this weekend in a 70-68 overtime victory over Texas State University, the Washington Post and several other media outlets reported in an Associated Press story. Hervey had eight rebounds and 33 points. He has accumulated 858 rebounds in his career, pushing him past Mack Collier who played for the Mavericks from 1999-2003.

New business venture

Stephen Newhart, UTA kinesiology doctoral student and adjunct professor, bought out his old boss, Larry North, owner of Larry North gym in downtown Fort Worth, the Star-Telegram reported. The gym currently has about 550 members. 

Federal budget

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, discussed the bipartisan agreement on the new $400 billion budget on KRLD Sunday Morning News. “It’s an old-fashioned deal in which both sides got a lot of what they wanted,” Saxe said. 

Dorothy Estes remembered

OA online celebrated the life of Dorothy Estes, who toiled for 27 years as student publications director at The University of Texas at Arlington and died recently at 90. At UTA, the feisty Estes won many awards, and so did her students who turned out the student newspaper, The Shorthorn.

Congressional races

UTA research scientist John Biggan was interviewed for a Star-Telegram article about the possibility that Republican incumbent Kenny Marchant may be defeated by a democrat in the District 24 U.S. House race.

Main Street

UTA is an official sponsor of the Main Street Fort Worth Arts Festival April 19-22, the Dallas Arts Dealers Association reported. Spanning more than 27 city blocks from the Tarrant County Courthouse to Sundance Square Plaza to the Fort Worth Convention Center, MAIN ST. will feature 223 juried artists from across the country.

Entrepreneurship, innovation

The Festival of Ideas, an annual event put on by UTA's College of Liberal Arts, focused on entrepreneurship and innovation, Dallas Innovates reported. UTA students as well as students from Arlington Independent School District and International Leadership of Texas attended. Several UTA faculty member and succesful alumni offered advice about what it takes to launch, grow and sustain a business.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, April 25, 2018
shortDescription: New College of Business deanHarry Dombroski, a longtime Hunt Consolidated and Hunt Oil Co. executive, has been appointed dean of the UTA College of Bu
body:
New College of Business dean

Harry Dombroski, a longtime Hunt Consolidated and Hunt Oil Co. executive, has been appointed dean of the UTA College of Business, Dallas Business Journal, Fort Worth Business Press, Austin Business Journal, Chicago Business Journal, Longview News-Journal and several other media sites reported. Dombroski earned his bachelor’s degree in accounting at UTA. 

Water recycling efforts

Zacariah Hildenbrand, co-founder and scientific contributor to Collaborative Laboratories for Environmental Analysis and Remediation team at UTA, speaks with Diana Nguyen for Marfa Public Radio about the team’s recent research on recycling produced water. Hildenbrand, through his partnership with UTA, has investigated potential links between unconventional drilling and water quality, collecting thousands of samples throughout the major shale plays in Texas, The Marshall News Messenger reported.   

Alumnus named dean

George Nnanna was selected as dean of the College of Engineering at the University of Texas of the Permian Basin, Midland Reporter-Telegram reported. Nnanna earned his master’s and doctorate degrees in mechanical engineering from UTA. 

Converging humanity, nature

Kevin Sloan, UTA’s associate professor in practice at the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, impressed the idea of continuing to converge humanity and nature in Dallas, Dallas Innovates reported. 

Israel's religious right

Brent Sasley, UTA associate professor of political science, shared his example of “the harmful global effects of the rise of the neo-nationalist/religious right in Israel” on Israel’s relationship with the diaspora, KopitiamBot.com reported. 

Alumnus named dean

Chris Shao has been appointed dean of Tarleton State University’s College of Business Administration, The Flash Today reported. Shao earned his doctorate degree in business administration-marketing at UTA and is a former professor here.  

New principal

Brandon Thurston was hired as the new principal at Liberty-Eylau Elementary School in his native town of Texarkana, Texas, the Texarkana Gazette reported. Thurston earned his master’s degree in education at UTA. 

Student volunteers

UTA students volunteered with the Arlington community by helping plant trees at Brantley Hinshaw Park as part of the NFL’s sustainability program, MyArlintonTx.gov reported. More than two dozen trees were planted ahead of this week’s NFL Draft.

Alumna candidate

Shatera Monroe-Robinson is a candidate running for the Jasper Independent School District Board of Trustees in Jasper, Texas, KJAS News reported. Monroe-Robinson earned her master’s degree in social work from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, December 6, 2017
shortDescription: Middle East analysisBrent Sasley, associate professor of political science in UTA’s College of Liberal Arts, provided live analysis on KRLD 1080 AM ab
body:
Middle East analysis

Brent Sasley, associate professor of political science in UTA’s College of Liberal Arts, provided live analysis on KRLD 1080 AM about President Trump’s pending announcement recognizing Jerusalem as Israel's capital and plans to move the U.S. embassy there. Sasley said while Trump likely feels this is the right thing to do to show Israel is a friend to America, the move could spark violence.

Russia's hybrid warfare

Patryk Babiracki, UTA associate professor of history, said the Kremlin has employed a new “hybrid warfare,” where all government and private resources can be mobilized to advance Russia’s goals, Medium.com reported. The story referred to a piece Babiracki wrote for The Washington Post.

Power of zinc

Zui Pan, UTA assistant professor of nursing, was featured in the India-based UdaipurTimes.com in an article about the power of zinc. Pan’s recent research found zinc helps slow down or even stop the growth of esophageal cancer.

Mitochondria research

UTA researchers have identified proteins in a signaling pathway in mammals that help mitochondria recover from stress, PublicNow.com reported. The discovery could pave the way for new treatments of cancer and some neurological diseases. Mark Pellegrino, UTA assistant professor of biology, was lead author.

Sexual harassment

Ann McFadyen, a UTA associate professor of strategic management, said sexual harassment has brought on bouts of depression, anxiety, stress and more in-depth psychological problems for victims, Health Day, WebMD and MedicineNet reported.

Professor honored

The American Chemical Society awarded Kevin Schug the J. Calvin Giddings Award for Excellence in Education, LCGC chromatographyonline.com reported. Schug is UTA’s Shimadzu Distinguished Professor of Analytical Chemistry and director of the CLEAR lab. Schug also contributed to chromatographyonline.com’s LCGC Blog with a post about the cannabis industry.

Flood mapping

UTA is working with the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers to improve flood warning and relief, reported phys.org. According to the story, Nick Fang, assistant professor of civil engineering in UTA’s College of Engineering, received a contract to help the Corps of Engineers improve its watershed mapping capabilities.

Groundwater research

Research conducted by UTA shows harmful bacteria levels in groundwater near hydraulic fracking sites in Texas, reported The Texas Standard. The research was led by Kevin Schug, UTA’s Shimadzu Distinguished Professor of Analytical Chemistry, and Zac Hildebrand, major contributor to UTA’s CLEAR lab.

Nagy appointed

Lisa Nagy has been named vice president for student affairs at The University of Texas at Arlington after a comprehensive, nationwide search, PublicNow.com reported.

Basketball season

The University of Northern Iowa hosts UTA in men's basketball on Thursday in Cedar Falls, Iowa, the Cedar Falls Courier reported. The matchup will pit UTA, ranked No. 2 among mid-majors by CollegeInsider.com, against UNI, which is ranked No. 12 in the same poll. The Lady Mavs face Kansas State tonight in Manhattan, Kansas, according to The Mercury.

Parade grand marshal

UTA men’s basketball head coach Scott Cross will be the grand marshal of Arlington’s annual Holiday Lights Parade, reported publicnow.com. The parade begins at 6 p.m. on Saturday, December 9, at Lampe and South Streets in Arlington.

Alumnus appointed

Agios Pharmaceuticals Inc., a leader in the field of cellular metabolism to treat cancer and rare genetic diseases, announced the appointment of Jacqualyn Fouse to its board of directors, StreetInsider.com and First World Pharma reported. Fouse earned a bachelor and master of arts in economics and a doctorate in finance from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, April 27, 2018
shortDescription: Nature paperUTA researcher Naomi Cleghorn has participated in a Nature paper that describes how humans thrived in South Africa through the Toba volcan
body:
Nature paper

UTA researcher Naomi Cleghorn has participated in a Nature paper that describes how humans thrived in South Africa through the Toba volcanic eruption about 74,000 years ago, which created a decades-long volcanic winter, Phys.org reported. Cleghorn, along with other researchers, studied a rock shelter called Pinnacle Point 5-6 near Mossel Bay, where they found an unusual shard of volcanic glass to determine that anyone had survived at all, the Daily Maverick reported. 

Math grant

UTA’s Department of Mathematics received a four-year, $998,652 grant from the National Science Foundation to continue a highly successful program that provides funds for high-achieving, financially disadvantaged undergraduate students to pursue degrees in mathematics, the Journal of Mathematics reported. 

CLEAR partnership

UTA’s Collaborative Laboratories for Environmental Analysis and Remediation has expanded its partnership with oil field equipment supplier Challenger Water Solutions to develop water recycling technologies that will transform waste from unconventional oil and gas development into reusable water, Life Science Weekly reported. 

Hervey could be steal

Kevin Hervey, UTA men’s basketball player and one of the most accomplished players in program history, is projected to be an under the radar player that the Dallas Mavericks might steal in the second round of the NBA draft, The Dallas Morning News reported. Hervey is set to graduate next month with a bachelor’s degree in education management. 

New vice president

Tommy Slater has been named vice president of Generating Assets for Southwestern Electric Power Co., ShelbyCountyToday.com, SWEPCO.com, TalkBusiness.net and The Gilmer Mirror reported. Slater earned a bachelor of science in mechanical engineering from UTA and is a registered professional engineer in Texas. 

Track athlete recruited

Alanah Moreno, a McAllen High School senior and cross country runner, signed a letter of intent to run with UTA’s Division I Track and Field team, the Rio Grande Valley's KGBT CBS 4 Sports reported.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, February 16, 2018
shortDescription: Remarkable growthThe University of Texas at Arlington's remarkable growth continues this spring with almost 43,000 students selecting UTA as their des
body:
Remarkable growth

The University of Texas at Arlington's remarkable growth continues this spring with almost 43,000 students selecting UTA as their destination for excellent academics, a career-focused education and a valuable college degree in critical workforce areas, Arlington TX reported. 

Cardiovascular grant

UTA researcher Mark Nelson has won a $3.3 million grant to study the influence of fat storage in the heart on cardiovascular disease, D Healthcare Magazine, U.S. Fed News and Medical Xpress reported. 

Toys beneficial

A UTA assistant professor’s research about how toys can support motor development in children was featured in Jakarta, Indonesia-based, Nakita.id. Priscila Caçola, a UTA assistant professor of kinesiology, led the research project.

Climate change analysis

Arne Winguth, chair of UTA’s Department of Earth and Environmental Sciences, was quoted in a Dallas Morning News article about climate change in North Texas. The story also cited a 2015 UTA study that predicted an increase in wildfires along paved highways, heat-induced stress on bridges and railroads, air-conditioning problems in public transport vehicles and heat-related accidents by failure of individual vehicles and heat-related stress. 

Interactive lectures

Mark Lamster, architecture critic of the Dallas Morning News and professor in practice in UTA’s College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, is developing a series of interactive lectures, panels and discussions on “Gentrified Dallas: A Monthlong Investigation into the Changing City,” The Dallas Morning News reported. The series starts March 1.

Bobadilla named
