The U.S. Hispanic Chamber of Commerce Foundation announced the selection of Michele Bobadilla as chair of its new University Partnerships initiative, NewsRX Health and Science and Education Letter reported. Bobadilla serves as assistant provost for Hispanic student success and senior associate vice president for outreach services and community engagement at UTA.

Outdoor art winner

Darryl Lauster, inter-media artist, writer and UTA associate professor of sculpture, is one of 10 winners of the fourth Ocala Outdoor Sculpture Competition, the Ocala Star-Banner reported. His sculpture, ”Untitled (Monument to John Glenn),” is a minimal scale replica of the Friendship 7 spacecraft flown by John Glenn during the first American orbit of the Earth in 1962.

Libraries exhibit

UTA Libraries’ exhibit of political cartoons by Etta Hulme received a positive review in the Dallas Observer. Hulme’s family donated more than 100 boxes of the cartoonist’s illustrations and papers to UTA after her death in 2014, librarian Beverly Carver says. While only a small portion of the collection is on display, Carver says it reveals how “we still deal with the same issues.”

Solo exhibition

New York Gallery Mark Strouse is presenting a solo exhibition of Texas-based artist Otis Jones, a former UTA associate professor and visiting professor, Artdaily.org reported. 

Alumna running for governor

Lupe Valdez, former Dallas County sheriff, is running for governor and relishes her underdog role, The Dallas Morning News reported. She received her master's degree in criminal justice from The University of Texas at Arlington.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, December 1, 2017
shortDescription: Bacteria in waterUTA researchers have discovered increased levels of bacteria in water near gas drilling sites, The Dallas Morning News reported. Kevi
body:
Bacteria in water

UTA researchers have discovered increased levels of bacteria in water near gas drilling sites, The Dallas Morning News reported. Kevin Schug, a UTA analytical chemistry professor and director of UTA’s Collaborative Laboratories for Environmental Analysis and Remediation, or CLEAR, led the studies, which were recently published in the peer-reviewed journal Science of the Total Environment. 

Robotics future

Robotics Tomorrow reported on the opening of UTA’s Emotional Robotics Living Lab, which aims to investigate what our future will look like with robots. Julienne Greer, UTA assistant professor of theatre arts, is director of the new lab.

Workplace behavior

Liliana Pérez-Nordtvedt, UTA associate professor of strategic management and international business in the College of Business, examined what is proper and improper behavior in the workplace based on the recent number of sexual harassment incidents, KXTX Telemundo 39 reported.

Sexual harassment

Sexual harassment is a continuing occupational health problem, according to a report published recently in the Journal of Occupational Health Psychology, Psychiatry Advisor reported. James Campbell Quick and M. Ann McFadyen, professor and associate professor in UTA’s Department of Management, respectively, wrote the report. The American Psychological Association’s Center for Excellence Good Company newsletter wrote a more in-depth article, saying that sexual harassment is a pervasive problem with a devastating toll on employee well-being and performance. Quick and McFadyen also were mentioned in a Pittsburgh Post-Gazette story about the spate of stories of sexual harassment in the workplace.

Barton stepping down

Rebecca Deen, chair of the UTA Department of Political Science, said U.S. Rep. Joe Barton, R-Arlington, said some would characterize the three-decade lawmaker as a “cantankerous” member of Congress, KERA 90.1 FM reported. She said she knows of many strong party supporters who were calling for his resignation, especially coupled with the sexual harassment dialogue across the country.

Biggins profile

D Magazine published a mini-profile on Lillie Biggins, president of Texas Health Harris Methodist. Biggins is a UTA nursing graduate.

Tax plan

Roger Meiners, the chair of the Department of Economics in the UTA College of Business, was one of 137 economists who signed an open letter to Congress supporting the Republican tax reform bill, CNBC and Business Insider reported. Meiners also is the UTA Goolsby Distinguished Professor of Economics and Law. The letter stated that the bill will lead to more jobs, higher wages and a better standard of living for the American people.

Deciding vote

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, said the GOP tax bill is so close in the U.S. Senate that Vice President Mike Pence could cast the deciding vote, Atlanta’s WGST 640 AM reported. Saxe said the bill was disappointing, hoping the measure would have been more radical.

Hearings analyzed

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, analyzed the hearings on President Trump and his administration on Memphis’ WREC 600 AM, saying that nothing very much comes from these investigations. He said politicians often grandstand during these types of hearings,

On-demand travel

Arlington will become a testing ground for a public transit system called Via that utilizes only on-demand shuttles, D Magazine reported. The article said some UTA students have complained because the arrival of Via means the end of Arlington’s one bus route from the UTA campus to DFW Airport. CityLab ran a similar story.

Land deal

Greysteel, a national commercial real estate investment services firm, has arranged the sale of a 5.1-acre development site adjacent to The University of Texas at Arlington, Dallas CityBizList reported.

Increase competition

Jordan officials need to do more regarding competitiveness as a way to increase financial investment in the country, the Jordan Times reported in a column written by Marwan Al-Shammari, an assistant professor of strategy at the Hashemite University and lecturer of management at The University of Texas at Arlington.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, December 4, 2017
shortDescription: Tax plan impactWashington's tax plans could pose big problems for DFW universities, especially their graduate enrollment, the Dallas Business Journal
body:
Tax plan impact

Washington's tax plans could pose big problems for DFW universities, especially their graduate enrollment, the Dallas Business Journal and its sister publications reported. According to the story, UTA has North Texas’ largest graduate student population, with an enrollment of 11,355.

Increased bacteria

UTA researchers have discovered increased levels of bacteria in water near gas drilling sites, U.S. News & World Report, KBTX CBS 3 in Bryan, Texas, and KOSA CBS 7 in Odessa, Texas, reported in carrying an Associated Press story. Kevin Schug, a UTA analytical chemistry professor and director of UTA’s Collaborative Laboratories for Environmental Analysis and Remediation, or CLEAR, led the research studies.

Basketball teams ranked

Kevin Hervey and Erick Neal helped the UTA men’s basketball team beat North Texas 65-60 on Saturday night at College Park Center, the Star-Telegram reported. The win is UTA’s fifth in a row. USA Today and many other outlets carried an Associated Press story on the game. Five of six writers from CBS Sports predicted the Mavericks, who CollegeInsider.com rank the No. 4 mid-major in the country, will win the Sun Belt Conference. CollegeInsider.com ranks the UTA women’s team the No. 11 mid-major in the country. Scott Cross, head coach for the men’s team, was also featured on BlogTalkRadio and the Screen the Screener college basketball podcast.

DACA effect

Alexandra Toribio, a UTA marketing major and Dallas resident who fled gang violence in her native Peru at age 7 with her parents, has struggled with severe anxiety since reports of DACA or Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program roundups surfaced, she said in a Newsweek story that also ran in Yahoo!News. The story questions federal authorities’ deportation powers. 

Saxe profiled

The Arlington Voice profiled Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, as one of Arlington’s most well-known political and philanthropic figures.

Robotics lab

The Arlington Voice reported on the opening of UTA’s Emotional Robotics Living Lab, which aims to investigate what our future will look like with robots. Julienne Greer, UTA assistant professor of theatre arts, is director of the new lab.

Film debuts

Patty Newton, a UTA film instructor, filmed City Hearts over six months in Grand Prairie, the Centre Daily Times in State College, Pa., reported. The film is about a group of 10 former inmates joining local artists to create a public art exhibit. The article originally ran in The Dallas Morning News. 

Fraternity helps

UTA’s Kappa Sigma fraternity hosted a supply drive for Caragh, an Arlington 5-year-old, who was raising money for local charities, the Arlington Voice reported.

UTA archeology lends hand

The UTA archeology department helped Burleson’s Hughes Middle School unearth time capsules that had been buried for 20 years, the Burleson Star reported.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, May 7, 2018
shortDescription: Business outreachHarry Dombrowski, recently appointed UTA College of Business dean, was interviewed by the Fort Worth Business Press about his new pos
body:
Business outreach

Harry Dombrowski, recently appointed UTA College of Business dean, was interviewed by the Fort Worth Business Press about his new position. “My area of focus is going to be outreach to the business community, and outreach to the community at large. And doing anything else I can to help the larger university,” Dombrowski said.

Hydrogel developed

Yi Hong, a UTA bioengineering professor and his team of researchers, have developed a highly elastic biodegradable hydrogel for bio-printing of materials that mimic natural human soft tissues, AZO Materials, Laboratory Equipment, Techsite, Environment Guru, Research and Development and Clinical Innovation + Technology. International coverage included Materialsgate of Germany, MedIndia and Diario de Antequera of Mexico.

Hormones, cholesterol link

Subhrangsu Mandal, UTA associate professor of chemistry and biochemistry, and a team of researchers are investigating the link between ovarian hormones and the blood cholesterol balance in the body, a key determinant of cardiovascular health or disease, Science Daily, Dallas Innovates, News-Medical.net, Medical Newser and R&D Magazine reported.

Jobs report detail

William Crowder, UTA professor of economics, was featured on KXAS NBC 5 discussing the positive national jobs report. “Right now Texas has one of the hottest job markets in the country,” Crowder said. “We are experiencing job growth and wage growth locally.”

New nursing officer

UTA instructor Rhonda Ross has been named associate chief nursing officer of Medical City Denton, the Denton Record-Chronicle reported. Ross is an adjunct instructor for the UTA College of Nursing and Health Innovation.

Protest organizer

UTA student Waed Alhayek was featured on KERA News for her work leading Rally4Reform, Saturday's anti-gun-violence protest, planned outside the Kay Bailey Hutchison Convention Center for the National Rifle Association Convention. "No one should have a military-grade weapon for defense and universal background checks are something that everyone can get behind because that ensures the right people are getting their hands on guns," she said. Her participation also was covered by radio stations across the country.

Citizen Bee winner

Future UTA student Kelvin Mote won this year’s Texas Citizen Bee on April 28 in Austin, the Amarillo Globe News reported. He won a $1,500 college scholarship.

Future student wins scholarship

Allison Fenske, a senior at Orcutt Academy High School who plans to attend the UTA and major in mechanical engineering, won second place for the Elks National Foundation Most Valuable Student Scholarship, Santa Maria Times reported.

Alumnus named engineering dean

UTA alumnus George Nnanna is the new dean of the College of Engineering at the University of Texas-Permian Basin, The Journal of Blacks in Higher Education reported. He holds a master’s degree and a doctorate in mechanical engineering from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, February 19, 2018
shortDescription: Maverick Speakers SeriesMichael Pollan will appear at 1 p.m. today on the radio program "Think," reported kera.org. Pollan will preview his lecture to
body:
Maverick Speakers Series

Michael Pollan will appear at 1 p.m. today on the radio program "Think," reported kera.org. Pollan will preview his lecture tomorrow night on the UTA campus as part of the Maverick Speakers Series. "Think" airs on KERA 90.1 FM.

NIH grant

Michael Nelson, a UTA assistant professor of kinesiology, will use a $3.3 million grant from the National Institutes of Health to study the link between fat storage in the heart as well as how gender can influence the development of cardiac dysfunction, Dallas Innovates and News-Medical.net reported.

Quiz competition

Academic WorldQuest, a quiz competition that tests teams' knowledge of current events and history around the world, was held last week at UTA, The Dallas Morning News reported. Plano West Senior High School clinched the win and will progress to the national competition in Washington, D.C.

Mobile device study

The Hindustan Times of India featured a UTA study that shows extra time spent on mobile devices after work can result in lower job satisfaction and create tension in marital life that spills over to the spouse’s workplace. Wayne Crawford, UTA assistant professor of management, collaborated on the study. 

Alumna running

UTA alumna Julie Oliver, attorney and controller for St. David’s HealthCare, is one of five Democrats running with hopes to unseat U.S. Rep. Roger Williams, the Austin-American Statesman reported. She earned a bachelor’s degree in accounting from UTA. 

New imam

Kamil Mufti, the new imam at the Islamic Centre of Longview and a native of Pakistan who has lived in the United States for 32 years, was interviewed by the Longview News-Journal on his new role. Mufti attended UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, December 13, 2017
shortDescription: NAI FellowDereje Agonafer, Jenkins Garrett Professor in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering at UTA, has been named a fellow of the National Academy o
body:
NAI Fellow

Dereje Agonafer, Jenkins Garrett Professor in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering at UTA, has been named a fellow of the National Academy of Inventors, the highest professional honor given to academic inventors, according to Dallas Innovates. 

Public transit

Diane Jones Allen, director of landscape architecture in UTA’s College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, provided insight to the Star-Telegram for a story about the City of Arlington’s new Via rideshare app. Allen recently authored a book about transit deserts, and she said Arlington falls into that category.

Panamanian politics

An interview with Sonja Watson, associate dean of academic affairs in the College of Liberal Arts, was featured in La Estrella de Panama, a Panamanian newspaper. The interview focused on Watson’s manuscript, “The Politics of Race in Panama.”

Political insight

There are crowded ballots in several local elections because of a trickle-down effect from the resignation of U.S. Rep. Joe Barton, R–Ennis, according to the Star-Telegram. In the story, Allan Saxe, UTA assistant professor of political science, described a political landscape in turmoil from top to bottom. Saxe also analyzed the Alabama senate race before yesterday’s election on WBAP 820 AM and KLIF 570 AM.

Transportation equity

Director of UTA’s Institute of Urban Studies Shima Hamidi offered analysis of her recent report on Dallas Area Rapid Transit on KERA 90.1 FM. Hamidi explained the equity challenges Dallas currently faces and explained why a new plan to optimize transportation tools that are already in place would benefit everyone.

Flood mapping

Nick Fang, assistant professor of civil engineering in UTA’s College of Engineering, is reviewing federal rainfall estimates in Texas, which could lead to major changes in the mapping of flood-prone areas, reported ASEE First Bell.

Researching mitochondria

A research team led by Mark Pellegrino, assistant professor of biology in UTA’s College of Science, has identified a protein in worms that helps mitochondria handle stress and repair damage, according to Mitochondrial Disease News. The protein could potentially help human mitochondria repair damage as well.

Sexual harassment

Research conducted by Jim C. Quick, Distinguished University Professor and John and Judy Goolsby–Jacqualyn A. Fouse Endowed Chair in the Goolsby Leadership Academy, and Ann McFadyen, associate professor of strategic management, about sexual harassment in the workplace was featured in Quartz.

Grant awarded

Professor Joohi Lee and Assistant Professor Mohan D. Pant of the Department of Curriculum and Instruction in UTA’s College of Education were awarded a 2017 research grant from Academic Partnerships, according to the Houston Business Journal and Corporate Media News.

BFA exhibit

An exhibit showcasing the work of graduating seniors from UTA’s bachelor of fine arts program is on display through Saturday in the Gallery at UTA, The Dallas Morning News reported.

Alumnus is featured speaker

UTA alumnus Jackie Davis was the featured speaker at the recent Dallas Court Appointed Special Advocate, or CASA, 20th anniversary Champion of Children Award Dinner, according to Park Cities People. The dinner raised $500,000. Davis was a foster child who now works for Dallas CASA and earned his master’s degree from UTA.

Table tennis

Yahao Zhang is the new coach of UTA’s Table Tennis Sport Club, The Dallas Morning News reported. Zhang brings a wealth of experience to the volunteer position, having won four collegiate titles while he was a student at Texas Wesleyan University in Fort Worth. UTA’s recreational team participates in National Collegiate Table Tennis Association tournaments.

Alumna hired

Medical City Fort Worth added a UTA alumna to its executive staff, according to D CEO Healthcare and Northeast News. Sunny Drenik, who earned a master’s degree in health care administration at UTA, joined the hospital as vice president of business development.

Improving transferability

In a column for Evolllution.com, UTA President Vistasp Karbhari challenged four-year universities and community colleges to work together to improve transferability. “We have no option except to put aside differences, break down silos, forget artificial spheres of influence and work in integrated fashion, putting the success of students first,” Karbhari wrote.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, February 2, 2018
shortDescription: Remembering Kalpana ChawlaDon Wilson, professor in the Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering Department in UTA’s College of Engineering, shared memorie
body:
Remembering Kalpana Chawla

Don Wilson, professor in the Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering Department in UTA’s College of Engineering, shared memories of his former student Kalpana Chawla with KDFW Fox 4, KTVT CBS 11 and the Star-Telegram on the 15th anniversary of Chawla’s death. Chawla earned her master’s degree from UTA before flying on two space shuttle missions. She was killed when the space shuttle Columbia broke up upon re-entry to the earth's atmosphere on Feb. 1, 2003. KXAS NBC 5, KRLD 1080 AM, the Economic Times, Indian Express and India’s Daily Hunt also reported on Chawla and her ties to UTA.

President speaks

UTA President Vistasp Karbhari offered remarks at the Indian consulate’s Indian Republic Day celebration in Houston, according to Indo American News. Other speakers at the event included Ashok Belani, executive vice president of technology, Schlumberger; Abidali Neemuchwala, CEO, Wipro; and U.S. Rep. Al Green, D-Houston. 

Urban partnership

La Bajada Urban Youth Farm Park near Dallas’s Trinity Groves restaurant complex allows economically disadvantaged high school students to learn about healthy food and environmental stewardship through paid internships, The Dallas Morning News reported. UTA’s School of Architecture in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs partnered with the non-profit Trinity River Mission to develop the farm.

ClaimBuster makes history

According to Poynter, the Washington Post last week published what is believed to be the first ever fact-check report developed from an automated alert. That alert was generated by ClaimBuster, a tool developed by Chengkai Li, computer science and engineering associate professor in UTA’s College of Engineering.

Moving toward commercialization

The REHEAL glove, developed at the UTA Research Institute, is moving closer to commercialization, according to Phys.org. Muthu Wijesundara, UTARI’s chief research scientist, recently received a grant from the Medical Technology Enterprise Consortium to develop a manufacturing process for the healing glove.

Visiting UTA

KUVN Univision 23 reported on high school students from across Dallas visiting UTA to get a taste of college life and learn about the excellence offered on the UTA campus. One potential student who hopes to study accounting said he was impressed with the university.

Harassment in healthcare

The healthcare industry is not immune to sexual harassment and the cost to an organization can be immense, reported Healthcare Dive. In the article, James Campbell Quick, Distinguished University Professor and John and Judy Goolsby-Jacqualyn A. Fouse Endowed Chair in the Goolsby Leadership Academy, offered expert opinion about how organizations can estimate some costs related to investigations and absences. He added that the cost in pain and suffering is difficult to measure.

UTA Dallas Office

UTA is expanding its presence in Dallas by opening a new office to help prospective students and their families obtain enrollment information and assistance, Informaté Magazine reported. The new UTA office in Dallas will eventually offer workshops and seminars at night and on weekends. It is located at 1111 W. Mockingbird Lane, Suite 1180.  

read a news excerpt

Architectural historian to speak

Kathryn Holliday, associate professor and architectural historian in UTA’s College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, will take part in a roundtable symposium entitled “People, Places and Politics of the City” on Monday, Feb. 5, publicnow.com reported. A senior planner for the city of Dallas and a social justice attorney will accompany Holliday on the panel. 

Alumna profiled

Roberta Scott, a UTA alumna and New Mexico native, was profiled in news-bulletin.com. Scott, an avid community volunteer, said she learned a work ethic from her days growing up on her family farm in Las Cruces, N.M.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, January 12, 2018
shortDescription: Tunnel researchResearch by Mohammed Najafi, UTA professor of Civil Engineering, focused on moving goods through an underground network of tunnels, was
body:
Tunnel research

Research by Mohammed Najafi, UTA professor of Civil Engineering, focused on moving goods through an underground network of tunnels, was featured in an article in The Fuse. The article highlighted automated technologies in the freight and logistics sector that will improve highway safety, reduce congestion and significantly cut fuel consumption. In a presentation at the Transportation Research Board annual conference in Washington, D.C., this week, Najafi pointed out that moving freight through underground pipelines is less expensive than rail or truck on a cost per mile basis.

Spotting fake news

Research by Chengkai Li, an associate professor in UTA’s Department of Computer Science and Engineering, focused on creating computer bots to spot and flag social bots that create and spread misinformation, was featured in an article about fake news in Fort Worth Weekly. The UTA project, entitled “Bot vs. Bot: Automated Detection of Fake News Bots,” focuses on Twitter accounts run by computer programs that automatically publish and forward content, follow other accounts, leave comments and conduct activity that seems “real” but isn’t driven by an actual person.

Women candidates

Rebecca Deen, UTA chair and associate professor of political science, was interviewed by Houston Public Media about the possibility that more women will be elected to Congress from Texas in 2018. Deen said women have often declined to run because the state’s Republican tilt worked against them. “Where you have a very strong one-party state,” she added, “it creates fewer opportunity structures for any kind of challengers. And then you couple that with the fact that women are more likely to run as Democrats and be successful in Democratic contests.”

Immigration issues

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, was interviewed by Talk Radio 640 WGST in Atlanta about immigration issues in the United States and the debate around Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals or DACA. “I think that DACA will be finalized, perhaps in a broader immigration bill,” he said. 

Mujeres Legendarias

Maria Martinez-Cosio, associate vice provost for faculty development at The University of Texas at Arlington, was one of just four North Texas women honored by Ford Motor Co. with a Mujeres Legendarias Award, 4-Traders, Education Letter and NewsRX Health and Science reported. Martinez-Cosio, who also is a UTA associate professor in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, was honored for leading efforts that resulted in transformational change on the UTA campus in the critical areas of access and success for traditionally underserved populations such as low-income, Hispanic or first-generation students.

Golf course to have Rangers moniker

The Texas Rangers baseball team and the city of Arlington have reached a first of its kind agreement that will put the team's name on Chester W. Ditto Golf Course, which has recently been renovated and redesigned, The Dallas Morning News reported. UTA director of golf Stuart Deane, who was at the meeting, said the school's golf teams look forward to using the facilities. John Colligan, an Arlington golf course architect, headed up the project. Colligan is a UTA alumnus.

Alumna named sales director

UTA alumna Lock Khemkeo has been named sales and marketing director at the Iris Memory Care’s newest location in Rowlett, New Vision and Star Local Media reported. Khemkeo earned her master’s degree in social work at UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, January 22, 2018
shortDescription: Robotics Living LabRobots are being created to help with tasks like disinfecting hospital rooms or alerting patients when it’s time to take medication
body:
Robotics Living Lab

Robots are being created to help with tasks like disinfecting hospital rooms or alerting patients when it’s time to take medications, Xconomy.com reported. A study at UTA’s Emotional Robotics Living Lab is even exploring how human-robot connection can help fight depression. Julienne Greer, an assistant professor of theatre at UTA, serves as the director of the lab, which was launched in November.

Pipe research

A UTA expert in pipe technology is investigating whether steam sealing of repaired pipes releases a noxious fume to determine if the process is dangerous to people, Phys.org, Facts of the Week and Techsite reported.

Water studies

Shale wells are swallowing twice as much water as they did a few years ago — around 10 million gallons each, or about 15 Olympic-sized swimming pools, the San Antonio Express-News reported. The article mentioned UTA’s Collaborative Laboratories for Environmental Analysis and Remediation or CLEAR Lab that was hired to study the water in natural gas drilling.

Survey course methods

Desiree Henderson, a UTA associate professor of English, draws upon the work of Larry Michaelsen to incorporate team-based learning in her American-literature survey course, a Chronicle of Higher Education column said in a compilation of how the survey course is being reinvented at various universities. In Henderson’s class, students work in permanent teams throughout the semester.

Government shutdown

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, offered his expert opinion that the federal government shutdown doesn’t have much of an impact on everyday people on KRLD 1080 AM and KMOX 1120 AM in St. Louis. Saxe added that the longer the shutdown lasts, the more of an impact it will have. Saxe also gave historical perspective about government shutdowns that occurred under Presidents Bill Clinton and Barack Obama in a San Antonio Express-News story. Saxe believes Congress will provide a short-term fix to the budget which will not end the immigration debate.

Pro-life, pro-choice stances

A poll which showed even political independents trend toward a pro-life stance would make it difficult for any candidate labeled as pro-choice to win a statewide office, Rebecca Deen, chair and associate professor of the UTA Political Science Department, said in a San Antonio Express-News story. She added that on the face of it, a Democratic candidate who isn’t a choice supporter will not likely get the Democratic nomination.

Workshop attendee

Jaehoon Yu, UTA physics professor, attended a UTA workshop about science education, computer engineering, bioengineering and other topics, The Korea Daily reported.

Gaming adding to innovation

Competitive gaming has taken hold at UTA where the university's Esports Club has experienced great success in national competitions, Dallas Innovates reported. The story said gaming is driving innovation in North Texas.

Food advocate

Michael Pollan, best-selling author and sustainable food advocate, is the next speaker in the Maverick Speakers Series, PublicNow and Arlington-tx.gov reported.

Cartoonist exhibit

The sixth floor of the UTA Library is featuring the work of Star-Telegram editorial page cartoonist Etta Hulme. For a time, Hulme was the only female editorial cartoonist working for a major metropolitan paper.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, April 20, 2018
shortDescription: Technology in disabilities grantUTA computer scientists and faculty associated with the disability studies minor in the College of Liberal Arts were a
body:
Technology in disabilities grant

UTA computer scientists and faculty associated with the disability studies minor in the College of Liberal Arts were awarded a $381,778 Research Experiences for Undergraduates grant from the National Science Foundation, Dallas Innovates reported.

Water recycling

Collaborative Laboratories for Environmental Analysis and Remediation at UTA has expanded its partnership with oil field equipment supplier Challenger Water Solutions to develop water recycling technologies that will transform waste from unconventional oil and gas development into reusable water, Engineering360, Techsite, sciencenewsline.com and Brinkwire reported.

Design-build project

UTA's College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, the City of Arlington and Housing Channel collaborated to create a design-build project that gives students the experience of designing and building a quality single-family home while working to provide affordable housing in the city, Fox 4 News and MyArlingtonTx.gov reported.

Trump approval rating

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, talked about President Trump’s approval rating and his upcoming dealings with North Korea on WBAP 820 AM.

First recruit inked

Chris Ogden, UTA’s new head men’s basketball coach, has signed his first recruit, Tyler Junior College point guard Brian Warren, who will join UTA in the summer, KYTX CBS 19 in Tyler, Star-Telegram and Tyler Morning Telegraph reported.

Alumnus named director

IA Interior Architects in Dallas hired David Lubin as co-managing director to grow the firm locally and nationally, retailenvironments.org reported. Lubin earned his bachelor’s degree in interior design from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, January 3, 2018
shortDescription: CLEAR-Apache renewalUTA’s Collaborative Laboratories for Environmental Analysis and Remediation, or CLEAR Lab, and Apache Corp. have extended their pa
body:
CLEAR-Apache renewal

UTA’s Collaborative Laboratories for Environmental Analysis and Remediation, or CLEAR Lab, and Apache Corp. have extended their partnership to study surface and groundwater quality in the Alpine High region of West Texas, The Houston Chronicle reported. This environmental research also was mentioned in a New Yorker article on the oil sector in Texas. 

PTSD research

Ashfaq Adnan, an associate professor in UTA's Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering Department, recently was awarded a three-year, $613,079 grant from the Office of Naval Research to show the potential link between blast-like trauma and neurological disorders such as post-traumatic stress disorder, Alzheimer's disease and Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy, or CTE, Techsite, News-Medical.net, and Phys.org reported.

Quick interviewed

James C. Quick, Distinguished University Professor and John and Judy Goolsby–Jacqualyn A. Fouse Endowed Chair in the Goolsby Leadership Academy,was cited in a Providence Journal article about sexual harassment in Rhode Island. Age differences between men and women and an increase in the number of women in a workplace can threaten some men’s image of themselves, Quick said. “It may appear aggressive,” he added, “but it’s really defensive behavior.”

Groundwater studies

Three new UTA research studies have found harmful pathogenic bacteria in groundwater near unconventional natural gas extraction sites in Texas, Environmental Monitor reported. Kevin Schug, associate dean of UTA’s College of Science and director of UTA’s Collaborative Laboratories for Environmental Analysis and Remediation, or CLEAR, led the research studies.

Surrogacy center

Heather Jacobson, associate professor of sociology in UTA’s College of Liberal Arts and author of “Labor of Love: Gestational Surrogacy and the Work of Making Babies,” was mentioned in a D Healthcare Daily article on how Dallas has become a major center for the surrogacy business. 

New laws analyzed

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, discussed the two dozen new laws going into effect on Jan. 1 in Texas with WFAA.com and the Star-Telegram. “Most people are very busy with their lives, trying to make a living and trying to escape from the daily grind of life, [and] laws and the Legislature are boring and often hard to understand,” Saxe said. 

MLK III featured

Martin Luther King III is the keynote speaker at the MLK Advancing the Dream Awards Banquet at 6 p.m. Jan. 12, the Star-Telegram reported about the region’s three-day celebration of the civil rights leader. Tickets for this event, at the UTA’s University Center’s Bluebonnet Ballroom, cost $55 and can be bought at www.utatickets.com.

RISE a capella performs

UTA’s RISE a capella student singing group was featured on WFAA ABC 8 before the winter break, provided holiday music during multiple newscasts. RISE appeared on Patti LaBelle’s holiday album. Dan Cavanagh, director of UTA’s music industry studies program and associate professor of music, arranged some of the songs on the LaBelle album while Jamar Jones, lecturer of music industry studies, produced it.

Bit coin detailed

John Podolanko, a UTA computer science graduate student, recently visited KERA 90.1 FM to detail the intricacies of bit coin and cryptocurrency during the program All Things Considered.

Alumnus named

UTA alumnus Kelcy Warren was named the 15th wealthiest Texan and 367th globally, East Texas Matters reported.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, April 16, 2018
shortDescription: Regents outstanding employeesTwo University of Texas at Arlington staff members are part of the 30-member inaugural class of UT System Regents' Outsta
body:
Regents outstanding employees

Two University of Texas at Arlington staff members are part of the 30-member inaugural class of UT System Regents' Outstanding Employee Award, U.S. Fed News reported. Molly Albart, director of Student Success, Planning and Assessment for the Division of Student Affairs, and Jeff Johnson, director of Maintenance Operations and Special Projects, will be honored at a May 14 special ceremony and luncheon in Austin at The Driskill Hotel.

DNA analysis

Roxanne Zascavage, assistant professor in UTA’s Criminology and Criminal Justice Department, gave expert opinion on forensic DNA analysis for a NBCDFW feature about a new trial using previously-untested DNA. "There are so many things you don't know,” said Dr. Zascavage. “It can say that an individual has touched this desk. It cannot say whether they touched it today or whether they touched it three years ago."

Unmanned vehicles research

A UTA researcher is developing metrics that can be used by unmanned aerial vehicle operators to help predict behavior of multiple vehicles flying at the same time, Dallas Innovates reported. The work by Kamesh Subbarao, associate professor in the UTA Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering Department, is being funded by a four-year, $795,427 Basic Research Grant from the Office of Naval Research.

UTA A Capella Choir

The UTA A Capella Choir accompanied the Fort Worth Symphony Orchestra during the Texas Ballet Theatre’s Mozart Requiem, Theatrejones.com reported. The live musical performance only intensified an already compelling evening.

Bangladesh adviser

UTA alumnus Sajeeb Wazed Joy is information and communications technology adviser to Bangladeshi President Sheikh Hasina, bdnews24.com reported. He received a bachelor in science in computer engineering from UTA.

Lifetime award

UTA professor emeritus of clinical science Ira Harvey Bernstein has been awarded the Albert Nelson Marquis Lifetime Achievement Award, Marquis’ Who’s Who reported. Dr. Bernstein is an expert in psychometrics, the field of study that involves the theory and technique of psychological measurement, or mental capacities and processes.

Council candidate

UTA alumna Jodi Vacars-Nance is running for Denton City Council Place 5, the Denton Record-Chronicle reported. She earned a master of science in social work at UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, April 23, 2018
shortDescription: Mobile device impactWayne Crawford, assistant professor in the Department of Management, co-authored a published study on how “Working on mobile devic
body:
Mobile device impact

Wayne Crawford, assistant professor in the Department of Management, co-authored a published study on how “Working on mobile devices from home may affect family life,” Indian24News.com reported. The study was published in the Journal of Occupational Health Psychology.

Vinylthon

Lance Liguez, UTA Radio faculty adviser and lecturer in the Department of Communication, talked to KDAF CW 33 about how College Radio Day’s annual Vinylthon is raising awareness for the original music medium.

Glass art

Justin Ginsberg, UTA’s area coordinator and professor of practice for UT Arlington’s Art and Art History program, talked about how the Arlington community has been essential in supporting the program, MyArlingtonTX.gov reported. The Glass Department’s 2100 Club is also curating special projects throughout the market season at Knapp Heritage Park.

Soldier saves lives

Candace Wimbish – UTA alumna and U.S. Army captain and chief of the Mojave Branch Veterinary Services at the U.S. Army Public Health Command in Fort Hood, Texas – saved the lives of several individuals while driving down U.S. Highway 62 in Yucca Valley, CA, 29palms.marines.com reported. Wimbish earned her degree in biochemistry at UTA.

Artist exhibit

Kathryn Hart, a multi-disciplinary artist, will present her first solo show “Searching” at the School of Visual Arts CE in New York City, ARTFIXdaily.com reported. Hart earned her masters of business administration degree from UTA and exhibits her art frequently in New York City, throughout Europe, and most recently, Los Angeles.

Research pioneer

Jean McSweeney is a research pioneer in women’s cardiovascular disease and recently received the Women’s Cardiovascular Health Professorship from the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences, newsedge.com reported. McSweeney earned her master’s in nursing from UTA.

Former adjunct running

Barbara Odom-Wesley, a former UTA adjunct professor, is in the running for the Arlington City Council District 1 seat, the Star-Telegram reported. Odom-Wesley offers her views on short-term rentals and transportation in north Arlington.

Outstanding volunteer

Hannah Farris, Arlington High School senior and co-chair of the FEMA Region VI Youth Preparedness Council, was recognized by the Arlington Fire Department for being an outstanding community member for the City of Arlington, MyArlingtonTx.gov reported. Farris wants to become a nurse to help others and plans to attend UTA this fall.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, January 17, 2018
shortDescription: Extending pipe lifeA UTA pipeline researcher has received a $400,000 grant from six state transportation departments and a national cooperative to cre
body:
Extending pipe life

A UTA pipeline researcher has received a $400,000 grant from six state transportation departments and a national cooperative to create design methodologies for extending the life of stormwater pipes, Dallas Innovates and PaintSquare.com reported. Mohammad Najafi, a professor in the Department of Civil Engineering, is spearheading the research through the university’s Center for Underground Infrastructure Research and Education.

Language study

Colleen Fitzgerald, UTA professor of linguistics, focused on her research regarding indigenous language revitalization and its connection to diversity in linguistics at a University of Michigan MLK symposium, Michigan Daily reported.

Women in elections

Rebecca Deen, UTA chair and associate professor of political science, delved into the possibility that more women would be elected to Congress, Rare Houston reported. The original article appeared in Houston Public Media. Deen said women have often declined to run because the state’s Republican tilt worked against them. 

Mobile device study

Natural News featured a story about a UTA study that finds that using a mobile device at home during family time can negatively impact family and work lives of both spouses. Wayne Crawford, assistant professor of management in UTA’s College of Business, was one of five authors on “Your Job Is Messing With Mine! The Impact of Mobile Device Use for Work During Family Time on the Spouse’s Work Life,” recently published in the Journal of Occupational Health Psychology. 

Chromatography study

Kevin Schug, UTA’s interim associate dean for research and development in the College of Science, analyzed the potential for use of different standards in gas chromatography in a column for The LCGC Blog. Schug also is a professor and the Shimadzu Distinguished Professor of Analytical Chemistry in UTA’s Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry.

New laws

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, said Texans are too busy with their lives to be concerned about new Texas laws that went into effect Jan. 1, the DefenderNetwork.com reported. The original piece ran in the Star-Telegram and outlined laws that recently took effect.

Chancellor named

Ronald Elsenbaumer, former UTA special adviser to the president, was selected as chancellor of Indiana University-Purdue University Fort Wayne, Inside Higher Ed reported.

Saxe weighs in on judges

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, questioned whether judges have the constitutional power to rescind some of President Trump’s executive orders on talk radio programs on WIBX 950 AM in Utica, N.Y., and WREC 600 AM in Memphis, Tenn. The WIBX report was simulcast on WFXV Fox 27. Saxe also appeared on KLIF 570 AM to offer insight into the outrage over comments President Trump made in a meeting about immigration with staff and congressional leaders.

MORe library cards

According to the Arlington Voice, Metroplex Online Resources or MORe library cards are available free of charge to all residents of Arlington, Pantego, Dalworthington Gardens and Mansfield. Students and employees of UTA and the Arlington and Mansfield school districts, employees of the City of Arlington, and all volunteers who work eight hours a month at the local library branches are also eligible.

Senior in record book

UTA senior center Rebekah VanDijk tallied 31 points and 18 rebounds against Arkansas State Saturday to become the first player in program history to record 1,000 points and 1,000 rebounds in her career, the Star-Telegram and the Amarillo Globe News reported.

MLK about community service

Martin Luther King III said that MLK Day is about community service and empowerment at the Advancing the Dream Awards Banquet held at UTA last week, newsedge.com reported. The son of the civil rights icon said that everyone's destiny is tied together and that everyone must treat women with respect and dignity.

Alumnus named principal

Baldwin Brown was named inaugural principal at I.M. Terrell Academy for STEM and Visual & Performing Arts, Fort Worth Business Press reported. Brown earned his master’s degree in educational leadership and policy studies at UTA.

Graduate hired as sales agent

Kevin Douglas has joined Southern Shores Real Estate Group LLC as a sales agent based in the Summerville office, The Post and Courier of Charleston, S.C., reported. Douglas received his master's degree in business administration from UTA. 

New assistant athletic director

Clay Cody, Marcus High School head boys’ basketball coach, has been named the new assistant athletic director for the Lewisville school district, the Lewisville Leader reported. Cody earned his master's degree from UTA.

Alumnus receives scholarship

Brandon Lacy received the One American Water Works Association scholarship, PublicNow.com reported. Lacy received a bachelor's degree in biology from UTA. In addition, Lacy was featured on the cover of Texas H2O, the TAWWA magazine.

Dean's List recipient

Paige Coleman, a history major, was named to the Dean’s List for the spring and fall 2017 semesters at the University of Texas at Arlington, College of Liberal Arts, the Lufkin Daily News reported. The Dean’s List recognizes students who have achieved a grade point average between 3.50 and 3.99 for the semester.

Institute lauded

An article in D Magazine complimented the work of the Institute of Urban Studies in The College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs. The story says UTA has become a center for the region's best thinking about public transit and affordable housing thanks in large part to the work of the institute under director Shima Hamidi.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, January 5, 2018
shortDescription: Online numbersUTA is among the leading colleges in the nation for online education, according to an Inside Higher Ed article that showed overall onlin
body:
Online numbers

UTA is among the leading colleges in the nation for online education, according to an Inside Higher Ed article that showed overall online student enrollment. UTA’s online enrollment is growing, reaching 21,330 in Fall 2016. 

American dream

The City of Arlington highlighted 19 stories during 2017 that epitomized people living the American dream in Arlington. Six of those stories featured people associated with UTA, including: Scott Cross, UTA’s head men’s basketball coach; alumnus Lou Diamond Phillips, Sedrick Huckaby, artist and UTA assistant professor of painting; alumna Shirley Patterson, Alexus Henry, UTA student-athlete and high jumper; and Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science.

Mujeres Legendarias

Ford Motor Co. honored Maria Martinez-Cosio, UTA’s associate vice provost for faculty development and associate professor in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, with a Mujeres Legendarias Award, according to Public Now, El Comunicador de Dallas and Scienmag. Mujeres Legendarias, or legendary women, is a national program honoring Hispanic women who are improving their communities. 

Affordable alternatives

Michelle Reed, an open education librarian at UTA Libraries, was featured in articles in EdSurge, College and University, and China’s Atman 360 about alternatives to printed textbooks. The stories highlighted Reed’s innovative efforts to encourage using open education resources as an affordable replacement for commercial textbooks.

Claimbuster test

UTA’s Claimbuster tool, which can mine lengthy transcripts for claims that fact-checkers might want to examine, forms part of a Tech & Check Cooperative project that will permit social media users to see instantaneous fact-checking appear on their device screen as soon as President Trump utters a claim in the Jan. 30 State of the Union address, Nieman Lab reported. The State of the Union will serve as the team’s first beta test.

Pain management

UTA researchers are focusing their attention on pain management in older adults, a segment of the population which presents a specific series of challenges to health providers, MD Magazine, National Pain Report, Psych Central, BioTech Week and Quality Stocks reported. “With 20 percent of Americans expected to be 65 or older by 2030, the development of new and effective pain management strategies is a necessity,” said Robert Gatchel, UTA Distinguished Professor of Psychology, who led the research. 

Water studies

UTA’s extended partnership with Apache Corp. on water quality studies in West Texas was featured on the investor website 4-Traders. Kevin Schug, associate dean of UTA’s College of Science and director of UTA’s Collaborative Laboratories for Environmental Analysis and Remediation, or CLEAR, is leading these studies.

Editorial cartoon exhibit

UTA Libraries will host a reception for the new exhibit “Drawn to Politics the Editorial Art of Etta Hulme” from 6 to 8 p.m. at the UTA Central Library Jan. 20, the Star-Telegram reported. The free exhibit highlights the work of former Star-Telegram cartoonist Etta Hulme.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, January 10, 2018
shortDescription: UTA national powerhouseLike the city itself, UTA has shed many stereotypes to become a national powerhouse, according to a Dallas Fort-Worth Real Esta
body:
UTA national powerhouse

Like the city itself, UTA has shed many stereotypes to become a national powerhouse, according to a Dallas Fort-Worth Real Estate Review of how Arlington has changed over the last 60 years. Arlington City Manager Trey Yelverton called UTA the largest economic generator in the city with an annual impact of $1.3 billion. “You need that brainpower developing,” Yelverton said. “What they put into the economy is significant, and we have to work hard to keep it strong.” The Real Estate Council and the Dallas Regional Chamber published the review.

Engineering praise

Study International published an article, “5 reasons to choose UTA for your degree in Engineering,” which highly praised UTA’s College of Engineering and UTA as a low-cost, well-located, top-quality research, diverse and growing institution. Study International connects students with a global network of universities.

Institute lauded

An article in D Magazine complimented the work of the Institute of Urban Studies in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs. The story says UTA has become a center for the region’s best thinking about public transit and affordable housing thanks in large part to the work of the institute under director Shima Hamidi.

Fair housing assessment

UTA researchers continue to collaborate with the City of Dallas on the Fair Housing Assessment, despite regulatory turmoil in Washington D.C., Myriam Igoufe, UTA doctoral student in urban planning and public policy, told D Magazine. Her team hopes to be able to present much of its work by June.

UTA discoveries

UTA’s partnership with the Botanic Research Institute of Texas was mentioned in a Dallas Innovates story about discoveries and new research in North Texas. The compilation of discoveries also mentioned a new vehicle lubricant that researchers in UTA's Tribology, Lubrication, and Coating Laboratory and ESL TEKnologies discovered.

Golf course renamed

UTA was mentioned in an NBCDFW.com article on the renaming of Arlington's Chester W. Ditto Golf Course to the Texas Rangers Golf Club, which would make the team the first in Major League Baseball to have a co-branded golf course. The City of Arlington had previously called together the Rangers, Arlington Convention and Visitors Bureau and UTA to work with Colligan Golf Design to redevelop the course into a "destination golf course that could be one of the best golf courses in North Texas."

Possible candidates

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, examined the rumors that Oprah Winfrey may consider running for President for CW33.com. "Oprah's a billionaire. Donald Trump's a billionaire. She's got a huge ego. He has a big ego. Let 'er rip!" said Saxe.

Mobile device impact

The New York Post, Government Executive, Morningstar, Guy Counseling and Moneyish featured a story about a UTA study that finds that using a mobile device at home during family time can negatively impact family and work lives of both spouses. Wayne Crawford, assistant professor of management in UTA’s College of Business, was one of five authors on “Your Job Is Messing With Mine! The Impact of Mobile Device Use for Work During Family Time on the Spouse’s Work Life,” recently published in the Journal of Occupational Health Psychology. The story received international coverage from HRKatha and Riautrust in Indonesia. 

Basketball players honor friend

A WFAA ABC 8 story featured UTA men’s basketball guard Kaelon Wilson and redshirt freshman Edric Dennis. Wilson wears the No. 5 jersey to pay tribute to a friend and fellow basketball player who died when they were teenagers. Dennis will continue the tradition after Wilson graduates, donning the number next season.

Textbooks decision

UTA senior Ursula Abdala was featured in an EdSurge article about how students choose which textbooks to buy for college courses. “I try to read the vibe of the teacher and see how it’s going to be,” Abdala said. “If I feel that one book will save my life this semester, I’ll break down and buy it,” she says. “I’m usually broke.”

College fair

UTA participated in an alumni college fair that provided college information to current students, KTRE ABC 9 in Pollock, Texas, and Waco's KXXV ABC 25 reported. High school junior Kayce Helton, who is planning to attend UTA appreciates hearing from former students. "It's interesting because everyone has a different experience,” Helton said.

Alumnus promoted

UTA alumnus Hamad M. Hamad has been promoted to principal in Dallas-based law firm Caldwell Cassady & Curry, PR Newswire and other media reported. Hamad has been honored as one of the state's top young lawyers since 2015 on the Texas Super Lawyers Rising Stars list by Thomson Reuters. He earned his undergraduate degree in biology, summa cum laude, at UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, January 29, 2018
shortDescription: Blood vessel studyUTA researchers are working to build new technology to study blood vessel function in heart failure patients, Dallas Innovates repor
body:
Blood vessel study

UTA researchers are working to build new technology to study blood vessel function in heart failure patients, Dallas Innovates reported. The research is led by Michael Nelson, assistant professor of kinesiology, in collaboration with Mark Haykowsky, Moritz Chair of Geriatrics in the College of Nursing and Health Innovation, and Fenghua Tian, a faculty research assistant in the Department of Bioenginering. Their work could lead to quicker diagnoses of heart failure and new life-saving treatments.

Educated workforce

UTA was mentioned among the strong universities that produce the Dallas-Fort Worth region’s educated workforce in a Kaplan Herald story about Texas’ chances to land Amazon’s second headquarters.

Recycling economics

Research conducted by Sahadat Hossain, director of UTA’s Solid Waste Institute for Sustainability, on the economics of recycling was referenced in a wfaa.com article about the city of Dallas’ attempts to force apartment buildings to offer recycling to residents. Hossain also is a UTA professor in the Department of Civil Engineering.

Creative partnerships

On KLIF 570 AM, Arlington Mayor Jeff Williams described current collaborations with UTA, Tarrant County College and Arlington school district which ensure skills needed by local companies are being taught as early as high school. Creative partnerships are ensuring students gain real-world job skills, building a strong college-to-career pipeline.

Estes remembered

Dorothy Estes, longtime director of UTA Student Publications who died last week, left her mark on multiple generations of journalists including many who work at The Dallas Morning News. The newspaper’s obituary honoring Estes painted a picture of a woman who was devoted to her student journalists, fiercely protecting them while also holding them to high standards. The Arlington Voice also featured a story about Estes.

Pittcon speaker

Kevin Schug, the Shimadzu Distinguished Professor of Analytical Chemistry in the College of Science, will be a featured speaker at The Pittsburgh Conference on Analytical Chemistry and Applied Spectroscopy, or Pittcon, according to AZoM. The report says Pittcon is the premier annual conference and exposition on laboratory science.

Stress management review

Jim C. Quick, Distinguished University Professor and John and Judy Goolsby–Jacqualyn A. Fouse Endowed Chair in the Goolsby Leadership Academy, offered an expert review of a report called Stress Management in the Construction Industry, according to satprnews.com.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, December 22, 2017
shortDescription: Pain managementUTA researchers are studying pain management in older adults, according to Science News Line, Technology Breaking News and MedicalXpres
body:
Pain management

UTA researchers are studying pain management in older adults, according to Science News Line, Technology Breaking News and MedicalXpress.com. Robert Gatchel, UTA Distinguished Professor of Psychology, Nancy P. and John G. Penson Endowed Professor of Clinical Health Psychology and director of UTA’s Center of Excellence in Health and Chronic Illness, and doctoral student Kelley Bevers led the research. Gatchel and Bevers first published their review paper in EC Anesthesia, an international peer-reviewed journal.

Working with the homeless

In an article nominating conductor Jonathan Palant for The Dallas Morning News Texan of the Year award, two UTA professors’ work with the Dallas Street Choir was mentioned. Courtney Cronley, assistant professor in UTA’s School of Social Work, and Anne Nordberg, also an assistant professor in the School of Social Work, are researching the choir’s impact on its homeless members’ lives.

Diversity recognition

Ashley Lemke, assistant professor of anthropology in UTA’s College of Liberal Arts, will receive a Diversity Field School Award from the Society for Historical Archaeology next month, according to publicnow.com. Lemke was recognized for her commitment to fostering diversity in a field school last summer. 

Groundwater research extended

The Apache Corp. extended its partnership with UTA’s Collaborative Laboratories for Environmental Analysis and Remediation, or CLEAR, the Fort Worth Business Press, Humanitarian News, Techsite and publicnow.com reported. CLEAR will continue to study surface and groundwater quality in the Alpine High region of West Texas.

Reviewing rainfall estimates

The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, or NOAA, asked Nick Fang, assistant professor of civil engineering, to review federal rainfall estimates for Texas. The research could lead to changes in the mapping of flood-prone areas, according to WRAL.com. The story about Fang’s work originally appeared in the Austin American-Statesman.

Cheaper high-speed internet

A team of researchers led by a UTA professor made a significant breakthrough that could lead to lower costs and less energy consumption for high-speed internet connections, newscaf.com reported. Michael Vasilyev, an electrical engineering professor in the College of Engineering, worked with a team from the University of Vermont to develop an optical medium in which multiple beams of light can autocorrect their own properties.

Honorary professorship

An honorary professorship was conferred upon Ishfaq Ahmad, a computer science and engineering professor in UTA’s College of Engineering, during an international conference at Amity University in Dubai, reported City Air News. Ahmad is a fellow of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, or IEEE, which was a co-sponsor of the conference on smart technologies for infrastructure and services.

Partnering with Patti LaBelle

UTA faculty members, students and alumni appear on legendary entertainer Patti LaBelle’s new holiday album, arlington-tx.gov reported. Jamar Jones, a lecturer of music industry studies and a UTA alumnus, produced the album. Dan Cavanagh, director of UTA’s music industry studies program, arranged sections of several songs and members of an a cappella student group provided background vocals.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, January 26, 2018
shortDescription: Turnout importantRebecca Deen, chair of the UTA Political Science Department and associate professor, told KERA 90.1 FM that this year’s Texas primari
body:
Turnout important

Rebecca Deen, chair of the UTA Political Science Department and associate professor, told KERA 90.1 FM that this year’s Texas primaries are more difficult to predict than previous years because of President Trump. She said turnout still provides an accurate gauge on how important primaries might be in a certain year.

NIH grant

Researchers from UTA are developing technology for cardiovascular health, XinhuaNet.com reported. Michael Nelson, an assistant professor of kinesiology and principal investigator of this new project, will work on the National Institutes of Health grant with two other faculty members. Their goal is to develop a device to study how oxygen is delivered to skeletal muscles and how those muscles utilize that oxygen. 

Brain paper

UTA researchers have published a paper in Scientific Reports that reveals how battlefield blasts may cause bubbles in the brain's perineuronal nets which, in turn, may collapse and damage neurons, Phys.org and Science Daily reported. Ashfaq Adnan, an associate professor of mechanical engineering, and postdoctoral associate Yuan Ting Wu published their research findings last summer. The team used Austin’s Texas Advanced Computing Center to crunch the numbers for the study.

Rogers named fellow

Jamie Rogers, Distinguished Teaching Professor and associate chair of UTA’s Industrial, Manufacturing and Systems Engineering Department, has been named a Fellow of the Accreditation Board for Engineering and Technology, Phys.org reported.

Robotic glove

UTA Research Institute scientists are developing soft robotic gloves to use in rehabilitation clinics and at home, IEEE Pulse magazine reported.

Survey caution

Fort Worth city council member Cary Moon released data from a survey showing a majority of the 684 participants opposed the city joining a lawsuit that challenges Texas’ sanctuary cities law, the Star-Telegram reported. Thomas Marshall, a UTA political science professor, offered expert opinion that officials should exercise caution when using such surveys as an accurate read of voter sentiment.

Amazon finalists

The two Texas cities – Dallas and Austin – still in the running to land Amazon’s second headquarters probably won’t rely on incentives as the main reason for nabbing the corporate giant, the Texas Tribune reported. Instead, experts say it will be a mix of lures that works for the two cities, including a well-stocked and vibrant higher education environment, which includes UTA. The Tribune story also ran in the Star-Telegram.

Photography exhibit

The work of Kenda North, photography professor in UTA’s Department of Art and Art History, is being featured in the “Seeing is a Nervous Habit” exhibit at Wichita Falls’ Midwestern State University through March 2, the Wichita Falls Times Record News reported.

Arlington's American Dream

Former Arlington Mayor Richard Greene, a UTA professor in practice in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, was featured in the city of Arlington’s American Dream series, PublicNow.com reported.

Conference speaker

LaTasha Jackson-McDougle, a UTA adjunct professor in criminology, will be one of the speakers at a conference on human trafficking at Heritage Oaks Church of the Nazarene, The Duncan (Okla.) Banner reported. Jackson-McDougle also is the founder of Cheryl’s Voice.

Dual credit

Red Oak school district is preparing students for when they leave public school with its Hawk Scholar Academy, the Waxahachie Daily Light reported. That program allows students to accumulate enough hours through dual credit classes to attain an associate’s degree by the time they graduate from high school. The report says those credits easily transfer to UTA.

Track star

The Mesquite News featured a profile on Greg Lautenslager, a track star turned author, newspaper writer and coach, who lives in New Zealand now. Lautenslager said his son, Craig, just graduated from UTA, where he set numerous school records and finished 13th last June in the NCAA 5,000-meter final.

Internship study

A Quartz column investigated the advantages and disadvantages of internships. The article mentioned a UTA study that found if interns had negative feelings about the experience, they were less likely to continue at that company and in the field. They also had greater incidences of withdrawal and depression at work.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, April 6, 2018
shortDescription: Blood pressure studyA new UTA study found that young, healthy black men exhibit greater increases in blood pressure than white males following spontan
body:
Blood pressure study

A new UTA study found that young, healthy black men exhibit greater increases in blood pressure than white males following spontaneous changes in nervous system activity when at rest, Medical Xpress and HospiMedica.com reported.

Nepal television interviews

UTA President Vistasp Karbhari and Jay Horn, UTA executive director in the Office of International Education, were interviewed about the UTA campus, international life, diversity and the role of higher education, Nepal’s News 24’s SDG Talk reported. UTA student Vishan Neupane conducted the interview.

Bone growth project

UTA is participating in a project that uses in situ 3-D printing for bone growth, Design News reported. The research will be undertaken in the UTA Bone-Muscle Group.

Future of technology

Aditya Das, division head of Automation and Intelligent Systems at the UTA Research Institute, was part of a Business for Breakfast panel talking about the future of technology, the Fort Worth Business Press reported. He said society is moving toward a techno-human environment where all the senses are used.

ClaimBuster tool

ClaimBuster, a fact-checking tool developed by a team of UTA researchers, was mentioned as one of the top such tools, NiemanLab.org and Poynter.org reported. While not yet fully automated, ClaimBuster is employing a feature that automatically scans CNN transcripts for fact-checkable claims, according to the article.

Glass art show

UTA’s Glass Art Sale and Show is 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. Saturday, April 7, at the Studio Arts Center, U.S. Fed News reported.

Alumna's work featured

Libby Newman’s work was featured at a Port St. Joe, Fla., exhibit, The Star reported. Newman earned her bachelor’s degree from UTA.

Scholarship winner

Brennan Linnell, a high school senior, will attend UTA on a Gainesville Area Visual Arts Association scholarship, the Gainesville Register reported.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, April 11, 2018
shortDescription: Online teaching advicePeggy Semingson, UTA associate professor of curriculum and instruction in the College of Education, offered advice for colleague
body:
Online teaching advice

Peggy Semingson, UTA associate professor of curriculum and instruction in the College of Education, offered advice for colleagues who are teaching online courses in a question-and-answer column in Inside Higher Ed. Semingson has been teaching online courses since 2008. She said online teaching has shown her that there is no one-size-fits-all approach and is responsive to students' needs.

Physicist lecture

David Nygren, UTA Presidential Distinguished Professor in the Department of Physics, will present a lecture on “The matter-antimatter asymmetry of the universe and the search for neutrinoless double beta decay” April 26 at the Hamilton Colloquium at Princeton University, EnvironmentGuru.com reported.

Nursing part of solution

UTA’s robust College of Nursing and Health Innovation should tie into a planned Fort Worth medical school and the JPS Health Network, a developer said in Bud Kennedy’s Star-Telegram op-ed column about how Tarrant County needs to expand health care now.

Vinylthon

UTA’s radio station is taking part in Vinylthon on April 21, The Dallas Observer reported. Vinylthon is a 24-hour event where DJs spin only vinyl records. UTA students who are participating would like to win the Golden Slipmat prize, which is awarded to the station with the best presentation.

Downtown Arlington

Downtown Arlington is undergoing a transformation that could make the destination another Magnolia Avenue or Bishop Arts District, the Star-Telegram reported. UTA, with its booming student population and large workforce, is a part of that changing landscape.

Math presentation

Jonghyun Yun, UTA assistant professor of mathematics, delivered a presentation on “Multicultural and Comprehensive Education” at a 2018 National Mathematics Competition seminar, The Korea Daily reported.

Mineral Wells downtown

UTA’s Institute of Urban Studies in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs has crafted a downtown redevelopment plan for Mineral Wells that is being instituted, the Mineral Wells Index reported.

UTA places third

UTA’s VORTEX team placed third in Arkansas’ 2018 VoiceJam Festival, an a cappella competition, NWA.com reported. VORTEX also earned the Fan Favorite Award.

Free online courses

Two hundred universities, including UTA, have launched 600 free online courses, OMGVoice.com reported. UTA is offering eight different courses in data science.

Esports arena

Arlington will build the largest esports arena in North America, Geek Reply reported. The article mentioned UTA and the increasing popularity of esports.

CPC on WNBA venue list

HeroSports.com is breaking down which WNBA venue is the best. UTA's College Park Center, home to the WNBA’s Dallas Wings, is on the list.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, January 8, 2018
shortDescription: Tier 1 pathUTA was featured as one of three North Texas universities moving toward Tier 1 status in the editorial letter of Dallas Innovates 2018, a n
body:
Tier 1 path

UTA was featured as one of three North Texas universities moving toward Tier 1 status in the editorial letter of Dallas Innovates 2018, a new magazine highlighting Dallas-Fort Worth as a hub for innovation. The region now has an inviting and collaborative entrepreneurial ecosystem, one that the Kaufman Foundation ranks 12th in the country in terms of startup activity, the editorial commented. 

Mobile device study

A UTA study finds that using a mobile device at home during family time can negatively impact family and work lives of both spouses, Science Daily, Phys.org, Psych Central, Asian News International, Iran Daily, the UAE’s Gulf Times and India’s Mid-Day, Medindia, Siasat Daily, Hindustan Times, New Kerala and Daily Pioneer reported. Wayne Crawford, assistant professor of management in UTA’s College of Business, was one of five authors on “Your Job Is Messing With Mine! The Impact of Mobile Device Use for Work During Family Time on the Spouse’s Work Life,” recently published in the Journal of Occupational Health Psychology.

Extending pipe life

Six state transportation departments and a national cooperative have awarded a University of Texas at Arlington pipeline researcher a $400,000 grant to develop design methodologies for lining their storm-water pipes with a sprayed polymer or cement-like material coating that can extend the design life of those pipes, Phys.org and Tech Site reported. Mohammad Najafi, professor in UTA’s Department of Civil Engineering, is leading the research through UTA’s Center for Underground Infrastructure Research and Education or CUIRE.

Mujeres Legendarias

Maria Martinez-Cosio, associate vice provost for faculty development at The University of Texas at Arlington, was one of just four North Texas women honored by Ford Motor Co. with a Mujeres Legendarias Award, U.S. Fed News reported. Martinez-Cosio, who also is a UTA associate professor in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, was honored for leading efforts that resulted in transformational change on the UTA campus in the critical areas of access and success for traditionally underserved populations such as low-income, Hispanic or first-generation students.

Possible political change

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, commented on the rising number of democratic candidates in Republican strongholds at the county level in North Texas for the Denton Record-Chronicle and The Dallas Morning News. "The Democrats are focused on Texas," Saxe said. "If they can turn Texas, oh, boy."

Preservation needed

Dallas’ Kalita Humphreys Theater, an iconic work by architect Frank Lloyd Wright, needs to be restored, according to Mark Lamster, associate professor in practice in UTA’s College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, and architecture critic of The Dallas Morning News. In an interview with KERA 90.1 FM, Lamster said the theater has never really been properly cared for, but a new conservancy could finally be the key to saving the structure.

Mavs win

Johnny Hamilton scored 18 points and gathered 12 rebounds as five UTA players scored in double figures as the Mavericks evened their Sun Belt Conference record by dominating South Alabama 91-67 on Saturday, Fox Sports, the Star-Telegram, AL.com and many other media outlets reported.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, January 19, 2018
shortDescription: Students work on adsUTA students helped produce three amusing video ads for the Dallas Sierra Club about climate change denial, AdChat DFW reported. F
body:
Students work on ads

UTA students helped produce three amusing video ads for the Dallas Sierra Club about climate change denial, AdChat DFW reported. Film students worked with Norry Niven, a film faculty member and UTA alumnus, and a number of other creative directors in North Texas to make the commercials.

Social impact winner

Samantha Crumrine won the 2017 Fig Scholarship for Social Impact, FigLoans.com reported. Crumrine is a UTA social work student who founded the Heart Gallery of Northwest Texas, which is a non-profit organization with a mission to connect children waiting in foster care with their forever families.

Student recognized

Maria Frias, a UTA civil engineering major, was recognized by the American Society of Civil Engineering as one of 2018’s new faces of civil engineering, ASCE News reported. Each year, ASCE recognizes 10 remarkable college students – young engineers in training whose early achievements mark them for greatness as professionals and point toward an optimistic future for civil engineering.

Fellowship winner

Kevin Park, a UTA architecture student, was selected to participate in the American Institute of Architecture Students CRIT Scholar fellowship program, Archinect reported. The program is supported by the AIA in partnership with several prominent architecture firms. Recipients receive a $1,000 grant for their research project and are matched with a mentor conducting research at an architecture firm. 

Alumna touts reconnection

Marian Brown, the recently appointed interim Dallas County sheriff, told WBAP 820 AM’s Rick Roberts that it’s imperative that law enforcement officials reconnect with the community. Brown is a UTA alumna. She was appointed to serve for Lupe Valdez, who resigned to run for Texas governor. Valdez is also a UTA graduate.

Government shutdown

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, downplayed the impending federal government shutdown by telling KRLD 1080 AM listeners that the majority of Americans won’t be affected that much by a shutdown. In another story on KLIF 570 AM, Saxe said that many politicians use vulgar language and that news reports of President Trump’s use of that language is overblown.

Alumnus named managing editor

Mark Bauer rejoined American Lawyer Media as managing editor of The National Law Journal and Texas Lawyer, Talking Biz News reported. Bauer is a UTA graduate.

Exhibition featured

The Ira M. Taylor Gallery will host Moving On: Photographs and Transmedia, Caleb Dulock’s latest exhibition, KIDY Fox 6 in San Angelo, Texas, reported. Dulock, a UTA graduate, is a Hardin-Simmons University art faculty member.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, April 13, 2018
shortDescription: UTA’s Department of Mathematics received a National Science Foundation grant to continue a highly successful program that provides funds for high-achi
body:
UTA’s Department of Mathematics received a National Science Foundation grant to continue a highly successful program that provides funds for high-achieving, financially disadvantaged undergraduate students to pursue degrees in mathematics, Phys.org reported.

Juhyun Lee, an assistant professor in the UTA Bioengineering Department, is using an American Heart Association grant to develop a new microscope that can capture 3-D motion, then adds time to construct a 4-D beating heart, Gene Therapy Weekly reported.

A new UTA study found that young, healthy black men exhibit greater increases in blood pressure than white males following spontaneous changes in nervous system activity when at rest, Hematology Week reported.

Voyage Dallas profiled Farhaj Mayan, a UTA graduate, and his business, FADE, which is a men’s lifestyle app. Mayan was accepted in the MassChallenge contest, a startup accelerator.

Doug Garner, UTA assistant director of campus recreation for adapted sports and head coach of the Movin’ Mavs wheelchair basketball team, is mentoring para swimmer Mohammad Shams Aalam Shaikh, Asian Age reported in profiling the intensive Global Sports Mentorship Program.

Brothers A.J. and Isaac Hummer will play for the UTA Movin’ Mavs wheelchair basketball team next fall, the Fort Wayne, Ind., Journal Gazette reported in a profile on the siblings.

The choral ensemble Verdigris will perform Saturday at The Planetarium at UTA, Theater Jones reported.

UTA’s radio station is taking part in Vinylthon on April 21. It's a 24-hour event where DJs spin only vinyl records, The Vinyl District reported.
