Charles Williams has been appointed to a three-year term on the South Carolina Hospital Association Board of Trustees, the Columbia, S.C., Regional Business Report said. Williams earned his master’s degree in business administration from UTA.

Anchorage Finance listed UTA as one of the best universities to pursue a master’s degree in social work.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, January 24, 2018
shortDescription: Cardiovascular technologyUTA researchers are developing technology to improve cardiovascular health, SINA English reported. Michael Nelson, an assista
body:
Cardiovascular technology

UTA researchers are developing technology to improve cardiovascular health, SINA English reported. Michael Nelson, an assistant professor of kinesiology and principal investigator of this new project, will work on the National Institutes of Health grant with two other faculty members to develop a device to study how oxygen is delivered to skeletal muscles and how those muscles utilize that oxygen. SINA English is a Chinese online media company.

Nursing diversification

Rising gender diversification is a good goal for the nursing profession, said Anne Bavier, dean of UTA’s College of Nursing and Health Innovation in a D CEO Healthcare column. She said the increasing number of men entering the nursing profession enriches the profession. Bavier also is immediate past president of the National League for Nursing.

Elections system

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, concluded that the system of Democrats and Republicans each having a representative in the Tarrant County Elections Department monitoring elections isn’t a big deal because both parties agreed to that system, KXAS NBC 5 reported in a story in which the county elections commission fired administrator Nathan Neblett just two weeks after it hired him.  

Government shutdown

Thomas Marshall, UTA professor of political science, told KDFW Fox 4 that if the government shutdown had lasted a couple of weeks, then it could have created some real-world and political problems. 

Israel visit

Brent Sasley, a UTA associate professor of political science, said Vice President Mike Pence’s visit to Israel was important to Israelis because he recognized Jerusalem as the country’s capital, WBAP 820 AM reported. He also said the recognition is important because it strengthens President Trump's political grip on the evangelical Christian voting bloc.

Immigration wrong topic

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, said the Democrats picked the wrong topic in immigration on which to justify a government shutdown, KLIF 570 AM reported.

Corrugated packaging teleconference

The International Corrugated Packaging Foundation will conduct its annual teleconference on the business of corrugated packaging and displays, and other career opportunities on Feb. 22, FlexoGlobal.com reported. UTA is one of 20 college campuses expected to participate.

Heroes of the Dorm

The Heroes of the Dorm video gaming tournament begins Feb. 6, ShackNews.com reported. UTA is the defending champion. Schools compete for more than $500,000 in scholarships.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, March 9, 2018
shortDescription: Parking garage openingKXAS NBC 5 reported on UTA’s opening of its west campus parking garage. The University will open a dining hall/student center an
body:
Parking garage opening

KXAS NBC 5 reported on UTA’s opening of its west campus parking garage. The University will open a dining hall/student center and residence hall later this year on the west side of campus.

Gas-to-liquid technology

Greenway Technologies Inc. announced the completion of the first of its kind G-Reformer®, which converts natural gas into synthesis gas, Global Newswire and many other media outlets reported. The G-Reformer® is a critical component of the company’s innovative Greer-Wright Gas-to-Liquids system which converts natural gas into liquid fuels. A team consisting of individuals from Greenway Technologies Inc. and its wholly-owned subsidiary, Greenway Innovative Energy, UTA and Industrial Refractory Services Inc. worked together over a three-day period to calibrate the newly built device.

Hervey, team hope to dance

A UTA basketball standout is dreaming about dancing, the Star-Telegram reported in a profile on Kevin Hervey. The 6-foot-9 star, who could be drafted into the NBA, said he wants the team to dance in this month’s NCAA Tournament. UTA is playing Appalachian State at 2 p.m. today in the Sun Belt Conference Tournament in New Orleans.

Stomp Wars 2018

Stomp Wars 2018 is being held at College Park Center Saturday, the Star-Telegram reported in a list of things to do this weekend.

Professor on panel

Arne Winguth, UTA associate professor of earth and environmental sciences, will serve on a panel at the North Texas Climate Change Symposium today, March 9, in Dallas, Dallas CultureMap and U.S. Fed News reported.

Choir featured

KZPS 92.5 FM aired UTA’s Rise A Capella choir’s Cheerios jingle at Walmart. Lone Star 92.5 Classic Rock also reminded listeners of the choir’s accompaniment of the Rolling Stones You Can’t Always Get What You Want two years ago at AT&T Stadium.

Transportation inequities

The Dallas Observer covered Shima Hamidi’s map depicting transportation inequities in Dallas. Hamidi is director of UTA’s Institute of Urban Studies and an assistant professor of urban planning in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs.

Ride-sharing service

Arlington is the first large city in the nation to drop public transit for a private ride-sharing service, Planetizen reported. Via Transportation began service in December, replacing MAX, a fixed bus route that ran between UTA and a commuter rail station near DFW International Airport.

Name recognition

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, predicted that Beto O’Rourke will have plenty of time to build name recognition before he faces U.S. Sen. Ted Cruz in the November election, Houston’s KTRH 740 AM reported.

Ensemble to perform

Verdigris Ensemble was profiled in a Dallas Art Dealers feature. The choir will perform at the UTA Planetarium in April.

UTA artist featured

Sedrick Huckaby, UTA assistant professor of art and art history, was featured in a Culture Trip story about notable artists in North Texas that people should know.

Student wins competition

UTA marketing senior Ryan Su won the 2017 Capsim Fall Challenge, an international business simulation competition, beating business students from 104 universities across 14 countries, NewsEdge.com reported.

Astronaut profiled

Kalpana Chawla, an American astronaut and the first woman of Indian origin in space, was featured in a NewsDog.com Women’s Day profile. Chawla, who died in the 2003 Columbia disaster, received her master’s degree in aerospace engineering from UTA.

Alumna featured

Marian Brown, Dallas County’s first black sheriff, was profiled in BallerAlert.com. Brown, interim Dallas County sheriff, will vie for the spot in the November election. Brown is a UTA alumna.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, February 14, 2018
shortDescription: Festival of IdeasThe path to becoming a successful entrepreneur doesn’t have to go through a business school — students with a liberal arts background
body:
Festival of Ideas

The path to becoming a successful entrepreneur doesn’t have to go through a business school — students with a liberal arts background can use their passion, creativity and ideas to change the world, Dallas Innovates reported in covering UTA’s Festival of Ideas. The aim of the event was to empower students to become entrepreneurs.

Triple axel physics

Andrew Brandt, UTA professor and associate chair of the Physics Department, told KXAS NBC 5 what’s needed physically to execute the triple axel jump. This week, Mirai Nagasu became the first skater in U.S. Women’s Olympic Team history to attempt and land a triple axel at the Olympics.

Recycling talk

Sahadat Hossain, UTA professor of civil engineering and director of the Solid Waste Institute of Sustainability, says creating diapers that could be recyclable would be a losing economic proposition, WOAI 1200 AM reported in a story saying that San Antonio is considering charging a $50 fee to homeowners who dump dirty diapers in recycling bins.

Blue Ribbon Panel

Diane Jones Allen, program director for landscape architecture in UTA's College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, participated in the American Society of Landscape Architects’ Blue Ribbon Panel on Climate Change and Resilience, Prism, NewEdge.com, WTOC CBS 11 in Savannah, Ga., and several other websites reported. The panel will release its recommendations this spring. The story was saluting African Americans during Black History Month.

Movin' Mavs named

Four current or former members of the UT Arlington Movin’ Mavs wheelchair basketball team have been named to the preliminary U.S. National team for the International Wheelchair Basketball Federation World Championships this August in Hamburg, Germany, the Arlington Voice reported. Movin’ Mav Fabian Romo and graduates Mike Paye, Aaron Gouge and Jorge Sanchez were selected to the 17-member preliminary squad.

Young architect

Austin architect Jamie Crawley was one of 18 recipients of the American Institute of Architects 2018 Young Architects Award, The Daily Telescope reported. Crawley is a UTA instructor in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs.

Star Wars engineering

Shivani Patel, a UTA aerospace engineering alumna, explained how a lightsaber is ripped apart and what caused an explosion in the most recent Star Wars movie, DesignNews reported. She now works for Houston-based GoEngineer.

UTA alumnus retires

Heritage planner John Calhoun, one of Windsor’s most visible public servants and ardent defenders of its history, has retired, CBC News reported. Since 2009, Calhoun was at the center of many of the most contentious debates over the Canadian city's built heritage. The Louisiana-born public servant earned a planning degree from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, March 19, 2018
shortDescription: Named to national boardMaria Martinez-Cosio, a UTA assistant vice provost for faculty development and an associate professor in the College of Archite
body:
Named to national board

Maria Martinez-Cosio, a UTA assistant vice provost for faculty development and an associate professor in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, has been elected to the board of the The Alliance of Hispanic Serving Institutes Educators, U.S. Fed News reported. 

Statewide award

Cindy Mohat, UTA business continuity planner and emergency management coordinator, received The President's Award at the 11th Annual EMAT Symposium in recognition of her substantial efforts to carry forward the goals and objectives of the Emergency Management Association of Texas, U.S. Fed News reported.

Endowed professor named

After a nationwide search, Delaina Price has been selected as the Fenton Wayne Robnett Assistant Professor of History at UTA, U.S. Fed News reported. Price earned a doctorate in history from Yale University, a master's degree in African American Studies from Yale, a master's degree in education from Harvard, and graduated summa cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa with bachelor's degrees in history and English from George Washington University.

Art judge

Benito Huerta, UTA art professor, is a judge of the Toyota Dream Car Art Contest, ENP Newswire reported. In August 2018, the top 30 world winners will win an all-expenses-paid trip to Toyota City, Japan, and participate in an awards ceremony, which includes a tour of a Toyota manufacturing plant. 

Students at gallery

Two UTA master of fine arts students, Billi London-Gray and Sara Rastegarpouyani, were invited to participate in this year’s MFA Invitational at 500X Gallery, the Dallas Art Dealers Association reported. Members of the 500X Gallery selected all of the artists through studio visits across the different campuses throughout 2017.

Design award winners

Two UTA students, Elena Chudoba and Andrew Czap, were recognized in PRINT’s Regional Design Awards for their work on Patriot Paddles, a line of ping pong paddles that celebrates the rush of game, American history, good times and freedom, Printmag reported.

Esports facility

UTA students were interviewed by the Star-Telegram, KXAS NBC 5,  CBSDFW.com, WFAA ABC 8 and many other national and international media about the new massive esports facility planned for Arlington. The city has already had some success in esports with a UTA club team winning a national championship in an event last year.

Open government seminar

UTA is hosting an open government seminar organized by the Freedom of Information Foundation of Texas in cooperation with the Texas Attorney General’s Office that will offer detailed training in state open government laws on April 17, the Star-Telegram reported. 

Acclaimed filmmaker

Jay Chern, a former UTA computer science and engineering faculty member, has become an acclaimed filmmaker after returning to Taiwan, the Hollywood Reporter reported. Now considered one of the most promising young talents in Taiwanese cinema, the 36-year-old director’s feature debut, Omotenashi, about the clashes between the old and new keepers of a traditional inn in Japan, is one of two films opening the 42nd Hong Kong International Film Festival.

Chlorine-treated water

Zachariah Hildebrand, UTA alumnus and scientific contributor to UTA’s Collaborative Laboratories for Environmental Analysis and Remediation, or CLEAR labs, was interviewed for a KXAS NBC 5 and NBCDFW.com story about concerns over chlorine-treated water. Hildebrand said that that the chlorine the authorities are using is not doing enough against bacteria.

Chawla's birthday anniversary

UTA alumna and astronaut Kalpana Chawla’s 56th birthday anniversary was celebrated this week, the International Business Times, Newsdog, Newstrack Live of India and Great Britain’s Eastern Eye reported. Chawla, who was the first Indian woman in space, completed her master’s degree in aerospace engineering at UTA.  She died in the 2003 Columbia disaster.

Alumna elected

UTA alumna Diana Alt has been elected to the board of directors of Hotel Brokers International, Hotel News Resource reported. She earned a UTA bachelor’s degree in marketing.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, April 18, 2018
shortDescription: Smart urban designDiane Allen, UTA’s associate professor in the Department of Planning and Landscape Architecture, contributed a column to American So
body:
Smart urban design

Diane Allen, UTA’s associate professor in the Department of Planning and Landscape Architecture, contributed a column to American Society of Landscape Architects’ The Dirt blog on “Why Smart Urban Design May Save Us from Natural Disasters and Address Social Justice.”

U.S. response

Brent Sasley, UTA associate professor of political science, talked to KLIF 570 AM about the United States’ response to Syria’s use of chemical weapons on its own people.

Comey book

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, offered his opinion on former FBI Director James Comey’s new book on President Donald Trump and the explosive social media language that has become part of the norm in the U.S. political scene, KLIF 570 AM reported. He also commented on former first lady Barbara Bush’s death.

Barbara Bush

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, said former first lady Barbara Bush, who died yesterday in Houston, was the matriarch of the Bush family. “She was a woman of few words, but very strong words,” Saxe said in stories that ran on KTAR 92.3 FM in Arizona, KOMO 1000 in Seattle, Wash., WINS 1010 AM in New York and WTOP 103.5 FM in Washington, D.C.

New Lady Movin' Mavs player

Elizabeth “Lizzy” Becker, a Charlotte Rollin’ Hornets basketball player and senior at Weddington High School in Matthews, N.C., will join UTA’s Lady Movin’ Mavs in the fall, Hornets.com reported. Becker, who made it to the final cut of the USA Women’s National Wheelchair Basketball Team selection process this year, is the fourth Rollin’ Hornet to play for UTA.

Alumnus selected

Deval Pandya, a data scientist in advanced analytics at Shell, has been selected to join the prestigious World Energy Council’s Future Energy Leaders program, the National Biodiesel Board reported. Pandya earned his doctorate in mechanical engineering from UTA.

Top CEO

UTA alumna Lisa Nguyen was selected as Top CEO of the Year for 2018 by the International Association of Top Professionals for her outstanding leadership and commitment to the industry, WICZ Fox 40 in Binghamton, N.Y. reported. Nguyen earned her master’s degree in accounting from UTA.

Small business award

Sugar Bee Sweets bakery in Downtown Arlington, owned by UTA alumna Heidi Allison, is a recipient of the 2018 Arlington Chamber of Commerce Small Business of the Year Awards, MyArlingtonTX.gov reported.

Art projects

UTA’s Art History Student Union and the Glass Department’s 2100 Club will be curating special projects throughout the market season at The Market at Knapp Heritage Park, a new family-friendly event in Downtown Arlington, MyArlingtonTX.gov reported.. Cheryl Mitchell, assistant professor in practice of Museum Studies at UTA, is organizing activities and volunteers.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, January 31, 2018
shortDescription: REHEAL gloveUTA received a grant from the Medical Technology Enterprise Consortium, a biomedical technology consortium which collaborates with multipl
body:
REHEAL glove

UTA received a grant from the Medical Technology Enterprise Consortium, a biomedical technology consortium which collaborates with multiple government agencies, according to Fort Worth Business Press. The grant will help Muthu Wijesundara, chief research scientist at the UTA Research Institute, develop the manufacturing process for the REHEAL glove. The REHEAL glove is a bioengineered glove that delivers medicine to injured hands.

State of the Union

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, analyzed President Trump’s State of the Union speech on WBAP AM 820. Saxe called the address a strong speech with a mostly domestic theme. He said Trump is effective when he sticks to his message. Saxe also complimented the speech writer for bringing emotion into the address.

Conference material

In a blog post on the LCGC Blog on chromatographyonline.com, Kevin Schug, Shimadzu Distinguished Professor of Analytical Chemistry in UTA’s College of Science, encouraged academic colleagues to bring fresh material to conference speeches. Schug was chosen to deliver the closing plenary lecture of a conference in the Czech Republic. A separate article in petro-online.com, lauded Schug, a pioneer of vacuum ultra-violet spectroscopy, for an excellent explanation of the process at PEFTEC, an international conference in Antwerp, Belgium.

Astrobiology examined

Manfred Cuntz, professor of astronomy in UTA’s College of Science, was a guest on Podcast on Natural Dallas. The episode, entitled Out of this World: Astrobiology, featured a conversation about the possibilities of finding life beyond earth.

Alumnus artist

Kevin Rubén Jacobs, a UTA alumnus who successfully launched two art galleries in Berlin, was profiled in D Magazine. Jacobs once owned a gallery in Dallas, but told the magazine it is difficult for artists to thrive in Dallas's art scene.

Contemporary nature of art

The work of Gregory Scott Cook, assistant professor of visual communications in UTA’s College of Liberal Arts, will be the featured exhibit in the gallery of Southeast Missouri State University, according to publicnow.com. The exhibit speaks to the contemporary nature of art in an environment that is increasingly digital and technology based.

Graduate named CFO

Green EnviroTech Holdings Corp. named Hernan Rizo as its new chief financial officer, reported 4-traders.com. Rizo earned an MBA from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, March 2, 2018
shortDescription: New center laudedThe University of Texas at Arlington, in partnership with the University of North Texas Health Science Center, is bringing massive ge
body:
New center lauded

The University of Texas at Arlington, in partnership with the University of North Texas Health Science Center, is bringing massive genome sequencing capabilities to North Texas through the launch of the North Texas Genome Center housed on the UTA campus, the Star-Telegram, The Dallas Morning News, TechSite, WICZ Fox 40 in Binghamton, N.Y., and many other websites reported.

Landscape architect profiled

Diane Jones Allen, director of landscape architecture in UTA’s College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs and a principal landscape architect of DesignJones LLC, was featured in a Total Landscape Care profile.

UTA chemist featured

Daniel Armstrong, UTA’s Robert A. Welch Distinguished Professor of Chemistry, was mentioned in a Petro Industry News article about a Merck product. The article referred to Armstrong's research on dicationic and polycationic ionic liquids.

Professor on jury

Austin's South by Southwest event announced that UTA’s Bart Weiss will be on the Texas High School Shorts jury, TulsaCW.com, StreetInsider.com and other media outlets reported. Weiss is an associate professor in filmmaking. He also is founder and director of Dallas VideoFest and produces Frame of Mind for KERA PBS 13.

New downtown plan

Mineral Wells City Manager Lance Howerton mentioned UTA’s Institute of Urban Affairs' work with the city and a city-appointed steering committee in creating a four-phase downtown plan, the Mineral Wells Index reported in coverage of Howerton’s state of the community address.

Relationship study

Women tend to have friendlier and more intimate interactions with gay men than straight men after learning of their sexual orientation, according to research published in the journal Psychological Science and reported in PsyPost.org. Eric Russell, a UTA research associate and the study’s author, said he had always been interested in the unique bond that straight women and gay men share.

SBC player of the week

UTA senior guard Erick Neal was named Sun Belt Conference Player of the Week, Best College Sports News Network reported. Neal led the Mavericks to a pair of home victories last week over Georgia Southern and Georgia State, averaging 20.5 points, 8.5 rebounds and 7.5 assists per game.

UTA Rise A Cappella

UTA’s Rise A Cappella, a student group, was chosen to appear in an online commercial for Cheerios and Walmart. The students recently also qualified for the semi-finals of the International Championship of Collegiate A Cappella to be held March 31 in Phoenix, Ariz.

Analyzing primaries

Rebecca Deen, UTA chair of political science, highlighted the 6th Congressional District race and other races on Austin’s KUT 90.5 FM and other Texas NPR stations. She said a large number of candidates in the Republican Primary might energize GOP voters to participate. The primary election is next week. The original story aired on Dallas’ KERA 90.1 FM.

Public housing meeting

UTA will lead a public meeting Thursday, March 8, reviewing residents’ comments and strategies for public housing in Garland, Public Now reported. A UTA team has been conducting an assessment of fair housing across 22 cities and housing authorities in North Texas during the last year.

Physician featured

Dr. Nancy Mutoro, an internal medicine physician, spoke at a Lompoc Valley Medical Center Auxiliary meeting about rural medicine, California’s Lompoc Record reported. Mutoro earned a bachelor’s degree in nursing from UTA.

Alumna named director

Susie Franscini Davis has been named director of McBee, an independent health care services and consulting firm, Crossroads Today reported. Davis received her bachelor’s degree in marketing from UTA.

New morning show anchor

Felicia Bolton was named a morning show anchor for WNCN CBS 17 in Raleigh, N.C., the Triangle Business Journal reported. Bolton received her bachelor’s degree from UTA.

Alumnus tabbed CFO

Michael Marquez was named interim chief financial officer of Tearlab Corp., 4-Traders.com reported. Marquez earned bachelor’s and master’s degrees from UTA in accounting.

New administrative position

Jeff Russell, principal of Decatur High School, has been named Denton Independent School District director of student and campus support services, the Denton ISD website reported. Russell received his bachelor’s degree from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, April 9, 2018
shortDescription: Ogden namedChris Ogden, formerly an assistant coach at Texas Tech and UT,  has been named UTA’s head men's basketball coach, an Associated Press story
body:
Ogden named

Chris Ogden, formerly an assistant coach at Texas Tech and UT,  has been named UTA’s head men's basketball coach, an Associated Press story on the ESPN website reported. The Star-Telegram, KXAS NBC 5 and many other media outlets also reported the story. The Star-Telegram also ran video interview with Jim Baker, UTA athletic director about the new coach.

Durant congratulations

One of new men's basketball coach Chris Ogden’s first endorsements came from Golden State Warriors star Kevin Durant, a former UT standout, in an article in The Dallas Morning News. “Congratulations to my friend [Chris Ogden] on becoming the next head coach for UT Arlington,” the current NBA All-Star and former Texas standout tweeted. “He is the true definition of a players coach! Big things ahead for him and his program.”

Malik family gift

UTA alumnus Raj Malik and his wife Mona have pledged $500,000 to endow need-based scholarships at UTA, The Dallas Morning News reported. The grants will be available to domestic and international students.

New microscope project

Juhyun Lee, an assistant professor in UTA’s Bioengineering Department, is creating a 3D motion microscope to examine how blood flow and cardiac muscle contraction affects gene development which leads to ventricular chamber development in the heart, Dallas Innovates reported. The work, which could one day help doctors identify heart abnormalities, is being funded by the American Heart Association.

Smart Homes

UTA’s Smart Homes initiative was featured in a DZone article about the importance of providing homes specifically designed for older living for the British market. The article listed UTA’s Smart Homes technologies, including sensors underneath tiles on the floor that will allow researchers to measure and evaluate changes in walking gaits and weight that might suggest illness or injury. The article also highlighted a special camera the system uses that is embedded in a bathroom mirror that will tell researchers about day-to-day heart rate, facial expression and skin color.

Book review

W. Marvin Dulaney, UTA emeritus professor of history, reviewed The Benefactors: Gold Factor, a thriller about the World War II-era Office of Special Services, a precursor to the CIA, BizWire Express, PR Web and Street Insider reported. “I was intrigued by the mixing of actual historical figures with fictional characters. I was also impressed by how the historical figures interacted with the fictional ones,” Dulaney said.

Improving language

Helen Abadzi, a former UTA visiting researcher in UTA's College of Education and former education specialist at the World Bank, commented in DotEmirates and The National newspaper in the UAE about the need to improve teaching of Arabic as pupils lag behind in their own tongue. “Whether you like it or not, research shows that Arabic students are not performing as well. For many, their reading of Arabic is a little slower than reading English," Abadzi said.

Theatre company featured

The newest Culture Buzz segment on MyArlingtonTV visits The University of Texas at Arlington for the Maverick Theatre Company's Heal The Divide On Campus, written and performed by students on April 4 in the Architecture Courtyard, U.S. Fed News reported. Viewers can find MyArlingtonTV programs on the following cable systems: Spectrum Channel 16 and AT&T U-Verse channel 99, and streaming capabilities at www.arlington-tx.gov.

Raising awareness

The U.S. Department of Labor's Occupational Safety and Health Administration and the National Grain and Feed Association formed an alliance to raise awareness about grain engulfment prevention and other hazards in the grain handling industry, guidance and access to resources to help protect employees, WorkersCompensation.com reported. UTA has established a website with information on hosting or participating in local stand-up events and educational resources for the grain industry.

UTA senior on roundtable

UTA public relations major Waed Alhayek participated in a roundtable on school violence with Education Secretary Betsy DeVos and gave her ideas on how to make schools safer, including universal background checks, a ban on bump stocks and a ban on high-capacity magazines, Al Dia  reported.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, April 2, 2018
shortDescription: Heart researchJuhyun Lee, an assistant professor in the UTA Bioengineering Department, is using an American Heart Association grant to develop a new m
body:
Heart research

Juhyun Lee, an assistant professor in the UTA Bioengineering Department, is using an American Heart Association grant to develop a new microscope that can capture 3-D motion, and then adds time to construct a 4-D beating heart, Phys.org and News-Medical reported. The researcher is working to determine how blood flow and cardiac muscle contraction affects genes that leads to ventricular chamber development in the heart.

Disaster workings

The National Science Foundation recently awarded two UTA researchers a grant to identify best practices to use from the response and recovery efforts during the bevy of 2017 natural disasters, Scienmag reported. Daniel Sledge, a UTA associate professor of political science, and Herschel Thomas, a UTA assistant professor of political science, will head up the research team.

Cancer imaging

UTA bioengineering professor Baohong Yuan is using a Cancer Prevention and Research Institute grant to develop better images for looking at deep tissue in the human body, Dallas Innovates reported. The effort’s aim is to detect cancer earlier.

3-D printing

UTA is participating in a project that uses in-situ 3-D printing for bone growth, Dallas Innovates reported. The research will be undertaken by the UTA Bone-Muscle Group.

Better battery

UTA is participating in a project that could create an efficient battery that would store energy that wind farms generate, AzoCleantech reported.

UTA highlighted

The Fort Worth Business Press celebrated its 30th year of publication by remembering some of the important events of those three decades. UTA’s soon-to-be-completed Science and Engineering Innovation and Research or SEIR building, the College Park District and College Park Center were highlighted. Another FWBP story highlighted the UTA volleyball team’s march to the Final Four in 1989.

Little impact

UTA’s Allan Saxe, associate professor of political science, said it’s very likely the government is sending a stern message about illegal voting, the Star-Telegram reported in a story about a Tarrant County woman who recently was sentenced to five years in prison for illegally voting in the 2018 presidential election.

Clinic receives grant

The Open Arms Health Clinic is growing with a $200,000 grant from the Arlington Tomorrow Foundation, U.S. Fed News reported. Fran Martin, a UTA retired nursing instructor, founded Open Arms in 2011 along with Dr. Bob Ure, a local family doctor, and Sandy Laird, a nurse practitioner and UTA nursing professor.

Scholarship recipient

The Vertical Flight Society awarded one of its 2018 scholarships to UTA’s Lorenzo Novoa, DMN Newswire reported.

Ensemble to perform

The Verdigris Ensemble will perform The Consolation of Apollo at 4:30 p.m. April 14 at the UTA Planetarium, NBCDFW.com reported. The concert is designed to take the audience on the astronaut’s journey to space.

Democrat voters will choose between Lupe Valdez and Andrew White in a May runoff election, Paper Blog reported. Valdez earned her master’s degree in criminology from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, March 7, 2018
shortDescription: Rise A CapellaKTVT CBS 11 and the United Kingdom’s One News Page reported on UTA’s Rise A Capella, a student group that appeared in an online commerci
body:
Rise A Capella

KTVT CBS 11 and the United Kingdom’s One News Page reported on UTA’s Rise A Capella, a student group that appeared in an online commercial for Cheerios and Walmart. The students recently also qualified for the semifinals of the International Championship of Collegiate A Cappella to be held March 31 in Phoenix, Ariz. The group has started a GoFundMe to help cover the cost of the Arizona trip.

New positions

Curtis Andressen, a seasoned administrator with more than three decades of higher education experience, is joining UTA as vice provost for international affairs, NewsEdge.com reported. In addition, Ashley Purgason has been named associate vice provost of student success at UTA.

Primaries analyzed

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, predicted on KRLD 1080 AM that national talk of Texas turning Democrat is happening way too soon. He said the fall 2018 election will come closer to determining whether Texas will switch over to more of a Democrat Party leaning. Saxe also appeared on KDFW FOX 4 and KXAS NBC 5. He said changing demographics in the state are more of a reason for a shift than negative feelings about President Trump. NBCDFW.com also ran the story.

Runoff in crowded race

Tom Marshall, UTA professor of political science, said openings in Congress are rare, the Star-Telegram reported in a story about runoffs after a crowded 6th Congressional District race. “Increasingly, once members of Congress are elected, they stay there a long time,” Marshall said. GVTC.com also ran the Star-Telegram story.

Garage opening

UTA will celebrate the opening of its new West Campus Parking Garage today, reported KXAS NBC 5. The opening of the 1,500-space parking garage at the corner of West Nedderman Drive and UTA Boulevard marks the completion of the first phase of a large west campus redevelopment project. A new residence hall and student dining complex will open in August.

Environmental topics

Research on polarizing environmental topics requires more than just analytical chemistry, said Kevin Schug, Shimadzu Distinguished Professor of Analytical Chemistry in UTA's Department of Chemistry & Biochemistry, in a Chromatography Online LCGC column.

Genome center

The University of Texas at Arlington, in partnership with the University of North Texas Health Science Center, is bringing genome sequencing capabilities to North Texas through the launch of the North Texas Genome Center housed on the UTA campus, D Healthcare and the Fort Worth Business Press reported.

Heart of Arlington

The Heart of Arlington Neighborhood Association, which includes UTA, was featured on the ArlingtonTX.com Meet The Neighbors web and video program. PublicNow.com also carried the story.

Alumna appointed

The Texas Higher Education Coordinating Board has appointed Stephanie Lassanske, a Tyler Junior College professor, to the Social Work Field of Study Advisory Committee, the Tyler Morning Telegraph reported. Lassanske earned her bachelor’s degree in psychology and master’s degree in social work from UTA.

Former softball player

KRIS NBC 6 featured Cheryl Fillmore during Women’s History Month. Fillmore, a local teacher, counselor and coach, also was an athlete in the West Oso school district. Fillmore played softball at UTA.

Korean professors workshop

Korea Daily reported on a workshop UTA held for Korean professors in Texas. The keynote speaker was Hyejin Moon, a UTA associate professor in the Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering.

Shepard appointed

Gov. Greg Abbott has appointed Janelle Shepard of Weatherford to the Texas Woman’s University Board of Regents, U.S. Fed News reported. Shepard, who is senior director of population health for Texas Health Resources, received her bachelor’s degree in nursing from UTA.

UTA student featured

UTA senior Richmond Escarlan was featured on a KXAS NBC 5 story about how the city of Arlington is revamping Abram Street through downtown.

Professor on panel

Arne Winguth, UTA associate professor of earth and environmental sciences, will serve on a panel at the North Texas Climate Change Symposium on March 9 in Dallas, U.S. Fed News reported.

Diverse communities

Five diverse activists, journalists and educators will explore whether the media fairly and accurately covers diverse communities in a free program at UTA Saturday, The Dallas Morning News reported.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, March 12, 2018
shortDescription: AbeXXa fundingUTA startup AbeXXa Biologics has received an initial investment from Boehringer Ingelheim Venture Fund and signed a collaborative resear
body:
AbeXXa funding

UTA startup AbeXXa Biologics has received an initial investment from Boehringer Ingelheim Venture Fund and signed a collaborative research agreement with the global company Boehringer Ingelheim, Dallas Innovates and Phys.org reported. UTA’s Jon Weidanz, co-founder of AbeXXA, biology professor, associate vice president of research and interim director of UTA’s North Texas Genome Center, underlined the importance of this financial support and technical collaboration for the startup, which is breaking new ground in research that could lead to the development of a menu-based approach to antibody-based therapies for cancer. 

Bike-share program

Meghna Tare, executive director of UTA's Institute for Sustainability and Global Impact, and Shima Hamidi, director of UTA's Institute of Urban Studies, were featured in a Star-Telegram article about Arlington and Fort Worth’s experiences trying to regulate bike-share companies. UTA launched an exclusive bike-share program with Zagster in August that includes 40 bikes at seven docking stations around campus.

Saxe on political trends

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, commented on the rising numbers of democratic voters participating in the Texas primaries for the Star-Telegram, McClatchy DC, Pressfrom.com and Political News: Current Politics and Events. Saxe also commented on why Texan voters are so forgiving of corrupt politicians in Political News: Current Politics and Events.

More female candidates

Rebecca Deen, UTA chair of political science, was interviewed by the San Antonio Express-News on the historic number of female candidates running in U.S. Congress and state House races. “If I had any message, it is the explanation this cycle is not simple,” Deen said, also noting that while the year is historic, it is difficult to know whether it suggests a larger trend.

Food bank need

Marti Harvey, UTA communication lecturer and newspaper columnist, published a column on how every college needs a food bank in the Dallas Morning News and College and University reported. Twenty-two percent of college students experienced "very low levels of food security that qualify them as hungry" according to an October 2016 report from the National Student Campaign against Hunger and Homelessness.

Dasgupta awards

UTA professor Purnendu Dasgupta has been honored with state and national awards for his work, Indiawest reported. Dasgupta, the Hamish Small Chair of Ion Analysis in UTA's Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, has been named the 2018 Distinguished Texas Scientist by the Texas Academy of Science and the 2018 American Chemical Society's Division of Analytical Chemistry Chemical Instrumentation Award recipient.

Tadpole research

An international team of researchers from UTA, University of Hamburg, University of Bern and the Bandung Institute of Technology in Indonesia, came across a curious tadpole in the remote forests on the island of Sumatra, Phys.org reported. To the amazement of the scientists, it turned out that the tadpoles possess a peculiar cup-like structure on their bellies, in addition to the regular oral disk found in typical tadpoles. As a result, the team described two new  species and a genus in the open access journal Zoosystematics and Evolution.

Sun Belt results

The UTA men’s basketball team upset top-seeded Louisiana-Lafayette on Saturday in a Sun Belt Conference Tournament semifinal, the Associated Press and many other media reported. The Mavericks, however, were defeated by Georgia State, 74-61, in the Sun Belt tournament finals, an Associated Press story said in The New York Times.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, March 28, 2018
shortDescription: Neutrino researchUTA researchers are leading an international team developing a new device that could enable physicists to better understand the neutr
body:
Neutrino research

UTA researchers are leading an international team developing a new device that could enable physicists to better understand the neutrino, a subatomic particle that may offer an answer to the lingering mystery of the universe's matter-antimatter imbalance, Phys.org, ScienceDaily, Newscaf, Physics and other media outlets reported. The researchers, who published their discovery Monday in Physical Review Letters, have demonstrated the effectiveness of their technique on a small scale.

Dasgupta honors

The Texas Academy of Science has named Purnendu “Sandy” Dasgupta of The University of Texas at Arlington the 2018 Distinguished Texas Scientist, The Dallas Morning News reported. Dasgupta, who is UTA's Hamish Small Chair of Ion Analysis, also received the American Chemical Society's 2018 Chemical Instrumentation Award.

Williams named Chi Epsilon president

Jim Williams, a UTA civil engineering professor, has been named president of Chi Epsilon, the national civil engineering honor society, U.S. Fed News reported.

Esports facility

UTA President Vistasp Karbhari welcomed the construction of an esports facility that city of Arlington officials recently announced will be located just a few minutes away from the campus, GIN or Game Industry News reported.

Gas-to-liquid technology

Gas-to-liquid technology, a collaborative research product by UTA and Greenway Innovative Energy, was featured on New to the Street, a program that aired on Fox Business News.

Main Street

UTA is sponsoring the main stage at the Main Street Fort Worth Arts Festival where various musical acts will perform, Dallas Uptown BubbleLife reported in a listing about events. Main Street will be held April 19-22.

Tariff impact

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, surmised that the effects of President Trump’s taxes and tariffs on steel and other products may not be finished affecting the U.S. stock market, KLIF 570 AM reported.

COE highlighted

SI News highlighted UTA’s College of Engineering graduate programs.

Student organizes marches

UTA senior Waed Alhayek helped organize local marches as part of the March for Our Lives gun control protest this past weekend, KXAS NBC 5 reported. The Dallas Observer also published a story about the march.

Composers symposium

Tim Ishii, UTA professor of jazz studies, will be part of the University of New Mexico’s 47th Annual John Donald Robb Composers’ Symposium, Silver City Sun News reported.

New CEO

Tom Lindquist has been named Allina Health and Aetna Insurance Co. CEO, Business Wire, Crossroads Today and other media outlets reported. Lindquist received his bachelor’s degree in management from UTA.

Community park help

UTA’s Institute of Urban Studies helped the city of Midlothian with development of its community park, the Waxahachie Daily Light reported.

Alumnus named director

Jay Wilbanks has been named director of project management at National Roofing Partners, PR Web and other media outlets reported. Wilbanks is a UTA business graduate.

Scholarship winner

Ashly Hizar, a UTA nursing student, received a Ransom Memorial Health Auxiliary scholarship, Canada’s Ottawa Herald reported.

New police chief

Mike Hamlin was named the new Grapevine police chief, the Star-Telegram reported. Hamlin earned his bachelor’s degree from UTA.

UTA students minister

Students from the UTA Baptist Student Ministry worked in San Antonio and Rockport during Spring Break as a way of spreading community ministry, Baptist Standard reported.

Band festival

Arkansas Tech University is hosting the Southern Regional Concert Band Festival, PublicNow reported. Students will learn from a cadre of university and professional musicians, including Ray Lichtenwalter, UTA emeritus director of bands.

New coffee, wine bar

A Dallas Observer story reviewed Urban Alchemy Coffee + Wine Bar, a recent addition to downtown Arlington, located near the UTA campus. Owner Tony Rutigliano ran the Downtown Arlington Management Corp. for six years, and his work there led him to open Urban Alchemy.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, February 21, 2018
shortDescription: UTA president featuredUTA President Vistasp Karbhari was featured in a Texas Tribune and Eagle Pass Business Journal article about fixing higher educa
body:
UTA president featured

UTA President Vistasp Karbhari was featured in a Texas Tribune and Eagle Pass Business Journal article about fixing higher education funding. “Having some type of performance funding tied to each institution’s mission, in addition to a consistent and stable model for funding would benefit Texas students and our economy,” Karbhari said. 

Karbhari receives award

UTA President Vistasp Karbhari received an award from the U.S. Pan Asian American Chamber celebration of the Lunar New Year, The Dallas Morning News reported. Chamber president Grace McDermott recognized Karbhari for his support for the local Asian-American community. 

Choosing venues

Rebecca Deen, UTA chair of political science, was interviewed by Texas Public Radio about how officials choose venues for primary elections. For those officials, picking the right size of venue is tricky. Deen said there’s some indication that this year's primaries may draw bigger crowds than usual — but who knows. “In some ways it's a guessing game on how many voters they think are going to come to the polls based on previous elections of those kinds, and then they make a determination,” she said.

Changing relationship

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, was featured on KTRH 740 AM in Houston discussing the changing relationship between Donald Trump and Ted Cruz. “They may not love each other, but they need each other. President Trump needs Ted Cruz. Ted Cruz needs President Trump,” Saxe explained.

UTA Libraries lauded

UTA Libraries Special Collections was praised as a true cartographic center in a WUSF 89.9 FM piece about a new cartographic library in Tampa, Fla. WUSF is the National Public Radio station in Tampa. "There are institutions that foster research and other institutions that have a display component, but you'd have to go to either the Library of Congress in Washington D.C. or the University of Texas at Arlington to see a true cartographic center that does all of those things in the same institution," said Rodney Kite-Powell, Touchton Map Library and Florida Center for Cartographic Education Director. 

Future UTA student featured

Future UTA student Yishai Benavides, who is in a project-based research design class at George H.W. Bush New Tech Odessa, is one of many high school students learning skills for when they are in college, the Odessa American reported. Benavides, a 17-year old-senior, has decided to become an electrical engineer and has already been accepted to UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, April 4, 2018
shortDescription: Finding flu remediesThe research work of UTA’s Yuan Zhou was featured in the UT System’s Texas Health Journal. Zhou, a UTA assistant professor in the
body:
Finding flu remedies

The research work of UTA’s Yuan Zhou was featured in the UT System’s Texas Health Journal. Zhou, a UTA assistant professor in the Department of Industrial, Manufacturing and Systems Engineering, recently did a study that uses a computer modeling approach to understand the process of flu transmission in public indoor spaces. That information is then used to help reduce transmission.

UTA record label

The UTA Department of Music was featured in a WFAA ABC 8 story about students starting their own record label, UTA Records and UTA Records X. Dan Cavanagh, associate professor of music, has been working with colleagues and students on the project for about a year. His aim is to give students a firsthand taste of the music industry. The story also ran on WFAA.com and San Antonio’s KENS CBS 5.

Nepalese documentaries

InfoPlus produced four-part documentary on Nepalese students attending U.S. universities, including UTA, which has 362 Nepalese students. The first segment of the documentary mentions UTA at the 3:44 mark. Active learning at UTA is at the 18:49 mark. UTA’s Homecoming is featured at the 20-minute mark. Episode 2 of the documentary interviewed UTA’s Suman Satyal, a physics lecturer/researcher who is of Nepalese descent. He is featured at the 5:10 mark. Troy Johnson, UTA’s vice president of enrollment management, talks about how UTA is open to all students at the 8:20 mark. Jay Horn, executive director of UTA’s Office of International Education, is interviewed at the 10-minute mark about cultural adjustments students encounter. Alaina Teplitz, the U.S. ambassador to Nepal, and Tristram Perry of the U.S. Embassy are interviewed in Episodes 3 and 4, respectively. The four-part documentary aired in prime time over three television networks in Nepal, on Kantipur TV and News 24. The visiting journalist program is supported by the State Department’s Foreign Press Center and American Embassy through the Media Co-ops program.

Soil analysis

Kevin Schug, Shimadzu Distinguished Professor of Analytical Chemistry in UTA’s Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, wrote a Chromatographyonline.com column about certain soil analyses.

UTA fair housing assessment

Gentrification is a part of Dallas’ changing landscape, a D Magazine article said. It mentioned a regional UTA assessment on fair housing that could be a part of Dallas’ look at a comprehensive housing policy.

Local author

Roger Broom, a local author, is one of the speakers at the Arlington Friends of the Library annual fundraiser, U.S. Fed News reported. Broom earned his master’s degree in finance from UTA.

Alumnus named project manager

Peter Dean has been named special project manager at Adolfson & Peterson Construction, MarketLine Energy/UtilitiesWire reported. Dean earned his master’s degree in business from UTA.

Radio award finalist

UTA Radio has been named a 2018 Radio Mercury Awards finalist for its production of "Mixed Signals," Radio and Television Business Report said.

Alumna named executive

Karla Ramberger was named chief nursing officer of Las Vegas’ Sunrise Hospital and Health Care, the Las Vegas Business Press reported. Ramberger earned her bachelor’s degree in nursing from UTA.

All Texas Academic Team

Hannah Lowe was named to the All Texas Academic Team, the Sherman (Texas) Herald Democrat reported. Lowe is transferring to UTA to complete her bachelor’s degree in education.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, March 5, 2018
shortDescription: Genome Center launchedThe University of Texas at Arlington, in partnership with the University of North Texas Health Science Center, is bringing massi
body:
Genome Center launched

The University of Texas at Arlington, in partnership with the University of North Texas Health Science Center, is bringing massive genome sequencing capabilities to North Texas through the launch of the North Texas Genome Center housed on the UTA campus, Phys.org, GenomeWeb, Dallas Innovates, ArlingtonTX and many other websites reported.

Dasgupta wins awards

Pernendu “Sandy” Dasgupta, the Hamish Small Chair of Ion Analysis in UTA's Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, has been named the 2018 Distinguished Texas Scientist by the Texas Academy of Science, Dallas Innovates reported. The article also said Dasgupta was named recipient of the 2018 American Chemical Society’s Division of Analytical Chemistry Chemical Instrumentation Award.

Hervey hits game-winner

Kevin Hervey launched a deep, game-winning 3-pointer that propelled the Mavericks men’s team to an 85-82 victory over Texas State, the Star-Telegram, Houston Chronicle, KXAS NBC 5, Washington Post and several other media outlets reported. The win secured a fourth-place seeding in the Sun Belt Conference Tournament later this week. UTA will play the winner of the Little Rock/Appalachian State game Friday, March 9, in New Orleans. The Lady Mavs clinched a third-place seeding in the women's Sun Belt Conference Tournament. They will play Thursday in New Orleans. 

DACA story

Luz Bolanos, a UTA graduate student earning her master’s in information systems while working as a paralegal, was profiled in a Star-Telegram story about the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals or DACA program.

Film/video students win

UTA film and video students won the Best of Show award for a Sierra Club public service announcement campaign at the American Advertising Federation-Fort Worth competition, the Fort Worth Business Press reported. Gold awards also went to UTA’s Cynthia Lama, Jessica Sanchez, Emily Brown and Kelley Willoughby. In addition to the gold awards, UTA took home eight silver and eight bronze awards.

Workforce program

Burleson residents have two weeks in which to submit Burleson Works Scholarship applications, PublicNow.com reported. UTA is a sponsor and educational partner in the program, which trains people for new positions in the workforce.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, March 21, 2018
shortDescription: Power coupleAcademic power couple Adrian Parr and Martin Zaretsky have joined UTA to strengthen the University’s focus on sustainable urban communitie
body:
Power couple

Academic power couple Adrian Parr and Martin Zaretsky have joined UTA to strengthen the University’s focus on sustainable urban communities, The Dallas Morning News, Benzinga, Public Radio International, The Street and many other media reported. Adrian Parr has been appointed dean of the UTA’s College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs and her husband Michael Zaretsky joins UTA's Department of Civil Engineering in the College of Engineering.

Genome Center

UTA researchers are positioning North Texas to become a hub for understanding your DNA, The Dallas Morning News reported. The North Texas Genome Center — a partnership between The University of Texas at Arlington and the University of North Texas Health Science Center — opened March 1 for commercial business. Right now, the center contains one $985,000 machine that can be used to map an entire genome. 

Tuition decision

The UT System Board of Regents approved raising tuition this fall and next at all universities, the Star-Telegram, KXAN News in Austin and other media reported. According to the UT System, even with the approved increases, the average student who receive financial assistance will see little to no increase in their out-of-pocket tuition and fee expenses.

MBA program

UTA’s MBA program is ranked No. 101 in the nation by U.S. News and World Report’s latest ranking of the best MBA programs in America, the Dallas Business Journal reported. 

Cal State Northridge dean named

Chandra Subramaniam, former interim dean of UTA’s College of Business, has taken a new position as dean of California State University, Northridge’s David Nazarian College of Business and Economics, SCV News of Santa Clara reported.  

UTA fraternity does good deed

UTA fraternity students dressed up in super hero costumes to brighten a sick child’s day, KXAS NBC 5 reported. Last week the fraternity took its Hero for Hope campaign to the Ronald McDonald house in Fort Worth. 

Student rally

UTA students are among the organizers of the March for our Lives to request more gun control, which will be held this Saturday in Dallas,  Dallas Observer reported. "We have three specific policies that we're really trying to push for," said Waed Alhayek, a UTA public relations major and one of the student organizers. "We want a ban on bump stocks and high-capacity magazines and to have universal background checks."

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, March 14, 2018
shortDescription: UTA lauded for serving veteransA Star-Telegram editorial said UTA is excelling in serving veterans. UTA has been ranked the No.1 four-year institution
body:
UTA lauded for serving veterans

A Star-Telegram editorial said UTA is excelling in serving veterans. UTA has been ranked the No.1 four-year institution in Texas for veterans — No. 12 in the nation — by Military Times, the editorial said. Under former combat veteran James Kumm, executive director of veteran programs, UTA has launched a veterans assistance website and plans to open a new Veterans Resource Center that will guide veterans from enrollment through career placement.

UTA ranked

Online-Degrees.com ranked UTA No. 6 in a new study of all Texas Colleges offering online degrees, Public Now reported. 

eSports venture

UTA President Vistasp Karbhari will be attending a major announcement Wednesday about a state-of-the-art eSports venture planned for the Arlington Entertainment District in the near future, Arlington Voice reported. 

Supereruption impact

Naomi Cleghorn, UTA associate professor of sociology and anthropology, participated in research on how humanity may have thrived after a volcano’s ancient supereruption 74,000 years ago, The New York Times, ABC News,  The Atlantic, Science and other media reported. The article was initially published in Nature. 

Professors quoted

James Campbell Quick, Distinguished University Professor and John and Judy Goolsby-Jacqualyn A. Fouse Endowed Chair in UTA's Goolsby Leadership Academy, and Ann McFadyen, a UTA associate professor of strategic management, were featured in an American Banker article on sexual harassment in the banking industry. “It goes back to culture and if sexual harassment becomes acceptable, then people who normally wouldn’t engage in it may do it, especially if powerful others are the ones doing it,” McFadyen said.

House report

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, commented on KLIF 570 AM about the report from the House Intelligence Committee that concludes that there has been no collusion between President Trump’s campaign and Russia. Saxe reminded listeners that the report has not been released yet and that the Democrats and intelligence agencies also will need to vet the content before releasing. 

Maverick Speakers Series

UTA’s Maverick Speakers Series will feature advocate and TV host Gretchen Carlson, U.S. Fed News and Public Now reported. Carlson is one of the nation's most successful and recognized news anchors and a tireless advocate for workplace equality and the empowerment of women. She most recently hosted The Real Story on Fox News. Prior to that, she co-hosted the No. 1-rated cable morning news show, Fox and Friends, for more than seven years.

Ride-sharing service

Via, an on-demand ridesharing service that is serving the UTA area, downtown Arlington and the entertainment district has worked well so far, International Business Times, San Antonio's KSTX 89.1 FM, KERA News, KUT 90.5 in Austin, the Texas Standard and many other media reported. 

Open government seminar

UTA is hosting an open government seminar organized by the Freedom of Information Foundation of Texas in cooperation with the Texas Attorney General’s Office that will offer detailed training in state open government laws on April 17, Lufkin Daily News reported.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, March 26, 2018
shortDescription: Governor visits IndiaGov. Greg Abbott is pitching Texas to various groups and entities in India, The Dallas Morning News reported. The governor said h
body:
Governor visits India

Gov. Greg Abbott is pitching Texas to various groups and entities in India, The Dallas Morning News reported. The governor said he was fascinated to learn that two Texas universities are run by Indian Americans. Vistasp Karbhari is president of the University of Texas at Arlington. Renu Khator is chancellor of the University of Houston system.

Art professor teaches Bush

Retired presidents turn to different pastimes after their tenures as commander in chief, The Rivard Report reported. George W. Bush turned to painting. One of his teachers, Sedrick Huckaby, is a UTA assistant professor of art. Huckaby was named one of the winners of the Outwin Boochever Portrait Competition 2016 hosted by The Smithsonian’s National Portrait Gallery.

Students march

UTA student Waed Alhayek was one of the thousands of students who participated in the March for Our Lives protest Saturday, The Dallas Morning News reported. “This is a moment. ... I believe in the Second Amendment, but I also believe in the right to live,” Alhayek told the crowd after describing the time she was held at gunpoint until police intervened. The activists were part of a nationwide protest in response to the recent Florida high school shooting that killed 17.

City boosts esports

UTA student Hui Nguyen, an esports player, said he believes the city of Arlington’s decision to build a $10 million esports venue will attract a lot of visitors, the Fairfield, Calif., Daily Republic reported. “Before, all of the tournaments were out of town and you had to travel. Now they’ll be here,” Nguyen said. The UTA esports team won a national championship last year. The Star-Telegram originally ran the article.

Gas-to-liquid technology

Greenway Technologies, a UTA partner in gas-to-liquid technology, announced the completion of its first G-Reformer®, the Kaplan Herald and other media outlets reported.

Study on arts, gentrification

Nicole Foster, a former UTA adjunct professor and doctoral graduate in the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, was mentioned in a CityLab.com article about the connection between the arts and gentrification. Foster and Carl Grodach, a former CAPPA associate professor, published a 2016 study on the issue.

EPA grant

UTA received an EPA grant dealing with sustainability assessment and decisions, Press Release Point reported. UTA was one of 31 schools nationwide receiving part of a total of $463,000 in EPA funding through the agency’s People, Prosperity and Planet or P3 grants program.

No-hitter pitched

Randi Carol Phillips, a UTA softball pitcher, hurled the sixth no-hitter in UTA history against Georgia State last week, the Longview News-Journal reported. Phillips played and graduated from Harleton High School near Longview.

Firm hires former adjunct

Burns & McDonnell has hired Jane Ahrens to its aviation design and project management team, the Fort Worth Business Press reported. Ahrens has taught courses in architecture and sustainability at UTA.

Alumnus lands job

Thomas Wyatt has joined Tax & Business Services as a tax associate, the Fort Worth Business Press reported. Wyatt earned his master’s in accounting from UTA.

Fire chief named

Paul Henley accepted the position of fire chief of Corsicana, the Corsicana Daily Sun reported. Henley received his bachelor’s degree from UTA.

DART route changes

A KXAS NBC 5 story about DART route changes mentioned a UTA study that concluded the transit agency does a poor job of serving the people who need it most.

Mexican student enrollment

El Diario de El Paso reported the enrollment of Mexican students at the UT El Paso campus has dropped. The article mentioned that UTA and other Texas universities are receiving foreign students to keep Texas third among states in foreign student enrollment.

Arm teachers with pepper spray

One Dallas Morning News columnist says the answer to better school safety could be arming teachers with pepper spray but not guns. Marti Harvey, a UTA journalism lecturer in the Department of Communication, wrote the op-ed piece.

Freedom of information

A one-day seminar about freedom of information will be held at UTA on April 17, the Denton Record-Chronicle reported.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, March 30, 2018
shortDescription: Nursing rankings The University of Texas at Arlington's nursing program continued its rapid rise in the latest U.S. News & World Report 2018 graduate
body:
Nursing rankings

The University of Texas at Arlington's nursing program continued its rapid rise in the latest U.S. News & World Report 2018 graduate school rankings, U.S. Fed News reported.

Fighting infections

A UTA professor is developing nanomaterial to defeat a superbug, KERA 90.1 FM and Houston Public Media reported. He Dong, associate professor of chemistry and biochemistry, is part of a team creating a new method to prevent these infections by developing a novel synthetic nanomaterial.

Vice president appointed

UTA has appointed Deborah (Dee) J. Robinson, vice president for development at the University of Cincinnati Foundation, as its first vice president for institutional advancement, U.S. Fed News reported. In this newly created position, Robinson will lead a division formed by the merging of the previous Office of Development and Alumni Relations, and University Communications.

Neutrino research

UTA researchers are leading an international team developing a new device that could enable physicists to better understand the neutrino, a subatomic particle that may offer an answer to the lingering mystery of the universe's matter-antimatter imbalance, News Medical reported. The researchers, who published their discovery Monday in Physical Review Letters, have demonstrated the effectiveness of their technique on a small scale.

Filling the gaps

The National Science Foundation recently awarded UTA professors a research grant to study and report how non-governmental organizations identify and fill gaps in the government's capacity to respond to a natural disaster, U.S. Fed News reported.

Upward mobility through transportation

Local entities, as well as the federal government, could promote upward mobility through better transportation policies, Shima Hamidi wrote in a column for the Eno Center for Transportation. Hamidi is executive director of the Center for Transportation Equity, Decisions and Dollars and director of UTA’s Institute of Urban Studies. The Eno Center for Transportation, created in 1921, seeks to promote safe mobility by ensuring traffic control and management.

Alumna first woman president

Waded Cruzado, Montana State University president, made history as the first female president at MSU, KTVH NBC 12 reported in a profile on Cruzado. She earned her doctorate in humanities at UTA.

Physical city lecture

Larry Scarpa, principal of Brooks + Scarpa and an affordable housing expert, will be the keynote lecturer on the Physical City at the Dallas Festival of Ideas April 7, The Dallas Morning News reported in a Mark Lamster column. Lamster is the DMN's architecture critic, a Loeb Fellow at the Harvard Graduate School of Design and a professor-in-practice at UTA’s College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs. UTA is a 2018 sponsor of the festival.

Study looks at services

A new study aims to define the diverse types of recovery support services and resources being offered to students at institutions of higher education, Crossroads Today reported. UTA’s Center for Students in Recovery participated in the study.

Astronaut profiled

Kalpana Chawla was featured in a profile in a Global Comment story. Chawla, an astronaut, died in the Columbia shuttle disaster. Chawla earned her master’s degree in aerospace engineering from UTA.

Airman in pilot training

Airman First Class Hoger Villegas Gaona was accepted into officer training school and the Air Force’s pilot training program, the Utah-based Hill Air Force Base website reported. The profile said Gaona earned his bachelor’s degree in aerospace engineering from UTA.

Alumna named executive director

Rebecca Cox has been named the new executive director of CASA, or Court Appointed Special Advocates of Denton County, the Cross Timbers Gazette and The Leader reported. Cox is a UTA graduate.

Organization founder

Rachel Lopez, a 27-year Mesquite resident who is founder and president of the Hispanic Forum of Mesquite, answered how she got involved in the organization and the community in a question-and-answer story with the Mesquite News. Lopez earned her master’s degree in social work from UTA.

Alumnus named vice president

Patrick Lee was appointed vice president of strategy at PharmaCord, PR Newswire and Markets Insider reported. Lee has a master’s degree in accounting from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Friday, March 23, 2018
shortDescription: Scholarship endowmentUTA alumnus Raj Malik and his wife, Mona, have pledged $500,000 to establish a permanent scholarship endowment to fund need-based
body:
Scholarship endowment

UTA alumnus Raj Malik and his wife, Mona, have pledged $500,000 to establish a permanent scholarship endowment to fund need-based scholarships for students, including international students, U.S. Fed News reported. The Maliks are now counted among the numerous donors who have made the dream of a college education possible for current and future students at UTA.

AIA Fellow

UTA professor Don Gatzke has been named a Fellow of the American Institute of Architecture, U.S. Fed News reported. Gatzke received the honor for "elevating architectural education by emphatically connecting architecture schools to the public and to the profession, and by helping to provide opportunities for students of diverse backgrounds," Texas Architect Magazine said.

New CAPPA dean

UTA not only invited Adrian Parr to become the dean of the College of Architecture, Planning and Public Affairs, but also hired her husband, Michael Zaretsky, to join UTA's Department of Civil Engineering, National News Agency and Archinect reported. Both come from positions with the University of Cincinnati.

AbeXXa receives funding

AbeXXa Biologics, named as one of the 40 Best University Startups1 in 2017, has received an initial investment from the Boehringer Ingelheim Venture Fund, Cancer Vaccine Week reported. AbeXXa also signed a collaborative research agreement with the global corporation Boehringer Ingelheim. "We're bringing our unique technology and know-how together with Boehringer Ingelheim's discovery and development expertise," said Jon Weidanz, co-founder of AbeXXa, biology professor and associate vice president of research and interim director of UTA's North Texas Genome Center.

Bone regrowth

UTA professors Marco Brotto and Pranesh Aswath were cited as collaborators in research on developing in-situ 3D printing for bone regrowth, Science Daily and  3D printing industry reported. The study’s leader, Venu Varanasi of Texas A&M, will now pursue this pioneering work further as part of the Bone-Muscle Group at UTA’s College of Nursing and Health Innovation, and in collaboration with UTA’s College of Engineering, Texas A&M University College of Engineering and College of Dentistry. Efforts are now underway to identify commercialization and scientific development for this emerging technology.

State of big data

Gautam Das, UTA Distinguished University Chair and professor of Computer Science and Engineering, explored the era of big data and data exploration on the Association for Computing Machinery SIGMOD Blog.

Political negotiations

Allan Saxe, UTA associate professor of political science, surmised on WBAP 820 AM that the show of U.S. military strength in the Korean peninsula moved North Korea’s leader Kim Jong-un closer to political negotiations with President Donald Trump.

EPA grant

UTA received an EPA grant dealing with sustainability assessment and decisions, NewsroomAmerica.com reported. UTA was one of 31 schools nationwide receiving part of a total of $463,000 in EPA funding through the agency’s People, Prosperity and Planet or P3 grants program.

Student films

Short films by four UTA students have been chosen to be screened at the 2018 BisonBison Film Festival in Ponca City, Okla., the Cowley Courier Traveler reported. The films are “1917” by Joshua Gallas, “Building the Sky” by Dylan Olmstead, “What Do You See” by Joseph Tesfaye, and “Darkness in the Shadows” by Nicolas Saenz.

Artist exhibit

Fabiola Valenzuela, a recent UTA fine arts graduate and a 2017 Texas Biennial artist, will be one half of the “Out of Focus” show at the Fort worth gallery, Fort Works Art, on Saturday, Spring Gallery Night, the Star-Telegram reported. See the spring gallery program here.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Wednesday, December 20, 2017
shortDescription: Surrogacy regionHeather Jacobson, associate professor of sociology in UTA’s College of Liberal Arts, provided perspective in The Dallas Morning News f
body:
Surrogacy region

Heather Jacobson, associate professor of sociology in UTA’s College of Liberal Arts, provided perspective in The Dallas Morning News for a story about the region’s emergence as a center for surrogacy, due to rapid developments in reproductive sciences. Jacobson spent more than five years researching surrogacy for a recently published book.

Bridge project

A UTA researcher was awarded a three-year contract from the Texas Department of Transportation to inspect, evaluate and monitor North Texas bridges, according to Tech Site. Nur Yazdani, a UTA civil engineering professor, will use non-destructive techniques to ensure bridges are capable of supporting their posted capacities.

New lizard found

Researchers from the Indonesian Institute of Sciences working in collaboration with scientists from The University of Texas at Arlington and Brawijaya University discovered a new species of lizard, Indonesia’s kumparan.com reported. The white spot lizard was found in Bukittinggi, West Sumatra. 

Tax plan analysis

Allan Saxe, associate professor of political science in UTA’s College of Liberal Arts, analyzed the tax plan expected to receive final Congressional approval today on WOOD 106.9 FM in Grand Rapids, Mich.

More efficient internet

Research conducted by UTA and the University of Vermont could make high-speed internet connections cheaper and more energy efficient, according to ASEE First Bell, EENADUIndia.com, African Planet, ETCIO.com, Optical Connections News and Electronics360. Michael Vasilyev, a UTA electrical engineering professor, developed an optical medium in which multiple beams of light can autocorrect their own properties without affecting other beams.

ClaimBuster use of algorithms

ClaimBuster, developed by Chengkai Li, a computer science and engineering associate professor in UTA’s College of Engineering, was mentioned in a Nieman Lab column about the need to use algorithms to automate online fact checking. Seriouslymedia.com published a similar column.

Groundwater studies

Three new studies conducted by UTA researchers revealed bacteria in groundwater near natural gas extraction sites, reported Natural News. Kevin Schug, Shimadzu Distinguished Professor of Analytical Chemistry at UTA and director of UTA’s Collaborative Laboratories for Environmental Analysis and Remediation or CLEAR, led the studies.

Backyard discovery

When a KXAS NBC 5 viewer discovered something in her backyard and wondered if it was a meteorite from the recent Geminid meteor shower, the station asked UTA planetarium director Levent Gurdemir to offer his expert opinion. Gurdemir said most the time a finding such as this is just a rock.

Alumna named interim sheriff

Dallas County’s new interim sheriff, Marian Brown, is a UTA alumna, according to the Dallas Observer. The sheriff's position was left vacant after Lupe Valdez stepped down to run for Texas governor. Valdez also is a graduate of UTA.

Alumnus profiled

Modern Counsel published a profile about Kelvin Sellers, general counsel and director of internal audit at Interstate Batteries. Sellers earned bachelor’s and master’s degrees from UTA’s College of Business before earning a law degree from Columbia Law School.

Principal appointed

D. Patrick Aziz has been appointed principal of Joslin Elementary in Austin, according to austinisd.org. Aziz earned a bachelor’s degree from UTA.

pageTitle: UTA In The News — Monday, December 11, 2017
shortDescription: Flood mappingThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, or NOAA, asked Nick Fang, assistant professor of civil engineering in UTA’s College
body:
Flood mapping

The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, or NOAA, asked Nick Fang, assistant professor of civil engineering in UTA’s College of Engineering, to review federal rainfall estimates for Texas. This research could lead to major changes in the mapping of flood-prone areas, according to the Austin American-Statesman. Fang created a flood warning system that helped protect Texas Medical Center during Hurricane Harvey.

Cancer research

Research conducted by Mark Pellegrino, assistant professor of biology in UTA’s College of Science, could lead to the development of new treatments for cancer and neurological disorders, reported Dallas Innovates. Pellegrino’s research was originally published in the Journal of Biological Chemistry.

Sexual harassment's toll

Health24.com reported on the stress that victims of sexual harassment experience, referring to research conducted by Ann McFadyen, associate professor of strategic management, and Jim Quick, Distinguished University Professor and John and Judy Goolsby – Jacqualyn A. Fouse Endowed Chair in the Goolsby Leadership Academy. McFadyen said bouts of depression, anxiety and stress are examples of psychological problems caused by sexual harassment.

Tweet featured

A tweet from The University of Texas at Arlington’s twitter account was highlighted by Newsweek and SFgate.com in San Francisco. When rapper Lil B tweeted that he wanted to pursue a degree in science or neuroscience, UTA replied with a link to an application and a suggestion that since he is already a trailblazer in the music industry, he should become a Maverick, too, after he earns a GED.

Alumna retires

After a 45-year career in health care, UTA alumna Lillie Biggins announced her retirement from Texas Health Harris Methodist Hospital in Fort Worth, the Fort Worth Business Press and D CEO Healthcare reported. Biggins, the hospital’s first female president, is a highly respected community leader. She earned a bachelor’s degree in nursing from UTA and will speak at the College of Nursing and Health Innovation's commencement ceremony on Thursday at 7 p.m.

Rideshare launches

Arlington’s new Via rideshare service launches today with service soon expanding to UTA, reported KDFW FOX 4. There is a $3 flat fee for each trip taken through Via.

Alumnus hired

Piper Jaffray Companies, an investment bank and asset management firm, announced the hiring of Harsh Kumar as a senior research analyst, financialbuzz.com, Tuscon News Now and KCTV CBS 5 in Kansas City, Mo., reported. Kumar earned an MBA from UTA.

Pottery on display

Pottery made by UTA alumnus Jef Barton was chosen for inclusion in the Art of Christmas Giving Show at Arlington’s Upstairs Gallery, according to dallasartdealers.org.

New position
